III. Sun leaves on the same tree are typically thicker than shade leaves, with more layers of palisade mesophyll.
IV. All leaves have the same internal anatomy regardless of environment.
options: TTTF
TTFT
TTFF
FTTT
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE. Xerophytic adaptations reduce water loss: thick waxy cuticle minimizes cuticular transpiration; sunken stomata in pits or grooves create a humid microenvironment above the pore, reducing the water vapor gradient; dense trichomes create a boundary layer of still air; additionally, some xerophytes have succulent water-storing tissue, rolled leaves (like marram grass), or reduce leaves to spines (like cacti). Statement II is TRUE. Hydrophytic leaf adaptations include: aerenchyma (large air spaces) that provide buoyancy and facilitate gas transport to submerged tissues; stomata on the upper (adaxial) surface only (in floating leaves like water lilies) because the lower surface contacts water; reduced or absent cuticle on submerged surfaces; and thin leaves to maximize gas exchange with the aqueous environment. Statement III is TRUE. Sun leaves and shade leaves (even on the same individual tree) differ dramatically: sun leaves are thicker with 2-3 layers of elongated palisade mesophyll cells (maximizing photosynthetic capacity per unit area); shade leaves are thinner with a single, less developed palisade layer but larger total leaf area (maximizing light interception). This plasticity is called heteroblasty or environmental heterophylly. Statement IV is FALSE. Leaf internal anatomy varies enormously in response to environmental conditions, species-specific adaptations, and developmental plasticity. C4 plants have Kranz anatomy; CAM plants have large vacuoles; xerophytes, mesophytes, and hydrophytes all have distinct internal organizations.

questions.question: The primary cell wall of a growing plant cell is composed primarily of:
options: Chitin microfibrils embedded in a matrix of glycoproteins
Keratin fibers cross-linked with disulfide bonds

Cellulose microfibrils (accounting for ~30% of wall dry weight) embedded in a matrix of hemicelluloses (cross-linking glycans), pectins (gel-forming polysaccharides), and structural proteins — this composite structure provides both strength and flexibility during cell growth
Pure lignin without any carbohydrate component
questions.explanation: The primary cell wall is a complex, dynamic composite material whose structure enables both mechanical support and cell expansion: (1) Cellulose microfibrils (~30% of dry weight) — these are the main load-bearing component. Each microfibril is composed of ~36 beta-1,4-glucan chains hydrogen-bonded in parallel to form a crystalline structure with tensile strength comparable to steel. Microfibrils are synthesized at the plasma membrane by cellulose synthase (CESA) complexes (rosettes). (2) Hemicelluloses (~25%) — cross-linking glycans (primarily xyloglucan in dicots, arabinoxylan in grasses) that hydrogen-bond to cellulose microfibrils, tethering them together into a network. During cell growth, expansin proteins disrupt these hydrogen bonds, allowing microfibrils to slide past each other. (3) Pectins (~35%) — acidic polysaccharides (homogalacturonan, rhamnogalacturonan I and II) that form a hydrated gel matrix filling the spaces between cellulose-hemicellulose networks. Pectins are cross-linked by calcium ions (Ca2+ bridges between homogalacturonan chains), contributing to wall rigidity. Pectins also mediate cell-cell adhesion in the middle lamella. (4) Structural proteins (~1-5%) — hydroxyproline-rich glycoproteins (extensins), glycine-rich proteins, and arabinogalactan proteins contribute to wall structure and signaling. Chitin (A) is found in fungal walls and arthropod exoskeletons. Keratin (B) is an animal structural protein. Lignin (D) is deposited in secondary walls but is absent from primary walls.

questions.question: A plant organ can be distinguished as a modified leaf rather than a modified stem by examining:
options: Its color only

Whether it has an axillary bud in its axil — true leaves subtend (have) axillary buds at the point where they attach to the stem, while stems bear leaves and their associated buds; thus tendrils, spines, and other modified organs are identified as leaf or stem derivatives based on their positional relationship to axillary buds
Its size only
Whether it is above or below ground
questions.explanation: Determining the homology (evolutionary origin) of modified plant organs requires understanding the fundamental positional relationships in the shoot system: (1) The phytomer — the basic unit of shoot construction consists of: a node (point of leaf attachment), an internode (stem segment between nodes), a leaf, and an axillary bud (in the angle/axil between the leaf and stem). (2) Positional criteria: (a) A true leaf subtends (has) an axillary bud at its base. If a spine, tendril, or other structure has an axillary bud in its axil, it is a modified stem or the axillary bud itself. If the spine/tendril IS in the position where a leaf would be (with an axillary bud at its base), it is a modified leaf. (b) Modified leaves: the spines of cacti (where leaves are reduced to spines), the tendrils of peas (where leaflets are modified into tendrils), floral organs (sepals, petals, stamens, carpels are all modified leaves). (c) Modified stems: the tendrils of grapes (modified axillary shoots), the spines of hawthorn (modified shoots), tubers (like potatoes — modified underground stems with 'eyes' that are axillary buds). (3) Additional evidence — vascular trace patterns (leaf traces vs. branch traces), developmental origin from the meristem (leaf primordia vs. axillary bud primordia), and gene expression patterns (KNOX genes are expressed in meristems/stems but excluded from leaves). Color (A), size (C), and position above/below ground (D) are unreliable indicators of organ identity.

questions.question: To test whether the auxin concentration gradient in the root tip is maintained by polar auxin transport (requiring PIN efflux carriers), a researcher should:
options: Apply the polar auxin transport inhibitor NPA (1-N-naphthylphthalamic acid) to the root and observe whether the auxin gradient (visualized using the DR5::GFP auxin-responsive reporter) is disrupted, and whether gravitropic bending is abolished — comparing wild-type roots with and without NPA treatment
Measure the total height of the plant
Count the number of flowers produced
Measure the chlorophyll content of the leaves
questions.explanation: Testing the role of polar auxin transport in maintaining the root tip auxin gradient requires pharmacological and/or genetic disruption of the transport machinery: (1) NPA treatment — NPA (1-N-naphthylphthalamic acid) inhibits polar auxin transport by blocking the activity of PIN auxin efflux carriers. Applying NPA to roots should: (a) Disrupt the normal auxin gradient (highest at the root tip, decreasing shootward). (b) This can be visualized using DR5::GFP or DR5::GUS reporters — synthetic auxin-responsive promoters that produce fluorescent or colored signals proportional to auxin levels. (c) In untreated roots, DR5 signal is strongest at the quiescent center and columella root cap. With NPA, the signal should become diffuse or redistributed. (2) Functional consequences — if polar auxin transport maintains the gradient, NPA treatment should also: abolish root gravitropism (which requires PIN-mediated lateral auxin redistribution), alter root growth rate, and disrupt lateral root initiation. (3) Genetic confirmation — comparing wild-type with pin2 (eir1) mutants or pin3 mutants, which have disrupted PIN carriers and show defective gravitropism, provides genetic evidence supporting the pharmacological results. (4) Controls — include: mock-treated wild-type roots (NPA vehicle only), NPA-treated roots with exogenous auxin applied to test if auxin response is intact even when transport is blocked. Plant height (B), flower number (C), and chlorophyll content (D) are not relevant to root auxin gradients.

questions.question: The concept of apical dominance in plants refers to:
options: The inability of plants to produce lateral buds

The phenomenon where the terminal bud (apical meristem) inhibits the growth of lateral (axillary) buds below it, primarily through auxin produced in the shoot apex that is transported basipetally (downward) — removal of the apical bud releases lateral buds from inhibition, resulting in branching
The dominance of root growth over shoot growth
The preference of a plant to grow toward light
questions.explanation: Apical dominance is a fundamental growth phenomenon that controls plant architecture: (1) The phenomenon — in an intact plant, the terminal bud (shoot apex) grows vigorously while lateral (axillary) buds along the stem remain dormant or grow slowly. This creates the characteristic conical shape of many plants (especially conifers). (2) Auxin's role — the classical model: auxin produced by the shoot apical meristem is transported basipetally (downward) through the stem's polar auxin transport stream. This polar auxin flow in the main stem prevents axillary buds from establishing their own auxin export stream (the 'auxin canalization' hypothesis), keeping them dormant. (3) Experimental evidence — Thimann and Skoog (1933) showed that removing the terminal bud (decapitation) releases lateral buds, and applying auxin (IAA in lanolin paste) to the cut stump restores lateral bud inhibition. (4) Modern understanding — apical dominance involves interactions between auxin, cytokinins, and strigolactones: (a) Auxin from the apex inhibits lateral bud growth. (b) Cytokinins (produced in roots and transported upward) promote lateral bud growth. (c) Strigolactones (produced in roots and stems) act synergistically with auxin to inhibit bud outgrowth, partly by dampening auxin transport from buds. (5) Practical applications — pruning exploits apical dominance: removing the terminal bud promotes bushier growth. Plants do produce lateral buds (A) — they're just inhibited. Root vs. shoot dominance (C) is a different concept. Phototropism (D) involves directional growth toward light.

questions.question: The bundle sheath cells surrounding vascular bundles in C4 plant leaves (Kranz anatomy) differ from typical mesophyll bundle sheath cells in C3 plants because C4 bundle sheath cells:
options: Lack chloroplasts entirely
Are smaller and less prominent than in C3 plants

Contain abundant chloroplasts with RuBisCO for the Calvin cycle, have thickened walls with suberin lamellae to prevent CO2 leakage, and are tightly packed around the vascular bundle — creating the distinctive wreath-like (Kranz) arrangement essential for concentrating CO2 at the site of RuBisCO activity
Are dead at maturity like xylem vessels
questions.explanation: Kranz anatomy (from German 'Kranz' meaning wreath or crown) is the distinctive leaf anatomy of C4 plants, characterized by modified bundle sheath cells: (1) Chloroplast-rich bundle sheath — C4 bundle sheath cells contain large, prominent chloroplasts (often with reduced grana), where RuBisCO and the Calvin cycle are localized. In contrast, C3 bundle sheath cells typically have few or no chloroplasts. (2) Suberin barriers — C4 bundle sheath cell walls contain suberin lamellae that reduce CO2 diffusion out of the bundle sheath. This is essential because the C4 pathway concentrates CO2 in bundle sheath cells (up to 10-fold higher than atmospheric levels), and this concentration would be lost if CO2 could freely diffuse away. (3) Tight packing — bundle sheath cells form a continuous, tightly packed layer around each vascular bundle, creating the wreath-like appearance. Abundant plasmodesmata connect mesophyll cells to bundle sheath cells for metabolite exchange. (4) Metabolic compartmentalization — in C4 photosynthesis: (a) Mesophyll cells: PEP carboxylase fixes CO2 into C4 acids (OAA, then malate or aspartate). (b) C4 acids are transported to bundle sheath cells via plasmodesmata. (c) Bundle sheath cells: C4 acids are decarboxylated, releasing CO2 at high concentration near RuBisCO. (d) RuBisCO fixes the concentrated CO2 via the Calvin cycle. Bundle sheath cells do have chloroplasts (A is wrong), are larger in C4 than C3 (B is wrong), and are alive (D is wrong).

questions.question: Leaf abscission (shedding) in deciduous trees involves the formation of an abscission zone. The cellular events in this zone include:
options: Rapid cell division to push the leaf off the stem

Enzymatic degradation of cell walls in the abscission layer through the action of cellulases and pectinases, combined with the formation of a protective layer of suberized cells on the stem side to prevent water loss and pathogen entry after leaf fall
Freezing of cells in the petiole base
Mechanical breakage of the petiole by wind alone
questions.explanation: Leaf abscission is a precisely regulated developmental process, not random breakage: (1) Abscission zone anatomy — a specialized region at the base of the petiole, containing smaller, thinner-walled cells that are more susceptible to enzymatic dissolution. The zone is established early in leaf development. (2) Hormonal control — the balance between auxin (which inhibits abscission) and ethylene (which promotes abscission) controls the timing: (a) While the leaf is active and healthy, it produces auxin that maintains the abscission zone in a non-responsive state. (b) As the leaf ages (senescence), auxin production decreases. (c) Increasing ethylene levels in the aging leaf sensitize the abscission zone cells to ethylene, activating abscission. (d) ABA also promotes senescence and ethylene production. (3) Cell wall degradation — ethylene-responsive genes in the abscission zone activate: cellulases (degrading cellulose microfibrils), polygalacturonases and pectinases (degrading pectin in the middle lamella), and other hydrolytic enzymes. The cell-to-cell adhesion weakens until the leaf separates. (4) Protective layer — before separation is complete, cells on the stem side of the abscission zone deposit suberin and lignin, forming a protective scar that seals the wound against water loss and pathogen entry. Vascular traces in the abscission zone are sealed by tyloses and gums. (5) Wind and gravity provide the final mechanical force to separate the weakened joint, but the enzymatic process is essential — leaves do not just freeze or blow off (C, D are wrong).

questions.question: Which of the following cell types is alive at functional maturity?
options: Tracheids
Vessel elements

Sieve tube elements — which are alive at maturity but highly modified, having lost their nucleus, ribosomes, tonoplast, and most organelles during differentiation to reduce resistance to mass flow, while retaining functional sieve plates, endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, and plastids
Sclerenchyma fibers
questions.explanation: Among the listed cell types, only sieve tube elements are alive at functional maturity: (1) Tracheids (A) — dead at maturity. Their protoplast (cytoplasm, nucleus, organelles) completely degenerates, leaving only the lignified cell wall with pits. The empty lumen conducts water. (2) Vessel elements (B) — dead at maturity. Like tracheids, they lose their protoplast, and additionally their end walls develop perforation plates (partial or complete openings). The empty tubes conduct water efficiently. (3) Sieve tube elements (C) — alive but uniquely modified. During maturation: (a) The nucleus degenerates (enucleate at maturity). (b) Ribosomes are lost. (c) The tonoplast (vacuolar membrane) breaks down, so the vacuole merges with the cytoplasm, creating a continuous lumen. (d) Most of the endomembrane system (Golgi, much of the ER) is lost. (e) What remains: plasma membrane, smooth ER, mitochondria, P-proteins (structural proteins), plastids, and sieve plates with open pores. (f) The cell depends on its companion cell for proteins, mRNA, and metabolic support. (g) The simplified interior reduces resistance to pressure-driven mass flow (Munch hypothesis). (4) Sclerenchyma fibers (D) — dead at maturity after depositing thick, lignified secondary walls. The empty lumen may persist but the cell is non-living.

questions.question: A researcher applies a pulse of radioactive CO2 (14CO2) to a single mature leaf of a bean plant and tracks where the radioactive carbon appears over the next 24 hours. The 14C is found concentrated in: (1) young developing leaves above the labeled leaf, (2) the root tips, and (3) developing fruit, but NOT in mature leaves below the labeled leaf. This demonstrates:
options: That xylem transports sugars from leaves to roots
That all plant tissues photosynthesize equally

That phloem transports photoassimilates (sugars) from sources (mature photosynthesizing leaves) to sinks (actively growing or storage organs including young leaves, root tips, and developing fruits) — following the source-to-sink model of phloem transport where the direction of flow is determined by the relative strength of sources and sinks
That radioactive carbon is toxic to mature leaves
questions.explanation: This classic pulse-chase experiment with 14CO2 demonstrates the source-sink dynamics of phloem transport: (1) Source — the labeled mature leaf is a source: it fixes 14CO2 into sugars through photosynthesis and exports these sugars into the phloem (primarily as sucrose). (2) Sinks — the 14C-labeled sugars are transported to three types of sinks: (a) Young developing leaves — immature leaves that cannot yet photosynthesize enough for their own growth needs, so they import sugars from mature leaves. (b) Root tips — actively growing meristematic tissues with high metabolic demand but no photosynthetic capacity. (c) Developing fruit — strong sinks requiring massive sugar import for seed development and fruit ripening. (3) Direction of flow — phloem transport follows pressure gradients from source (high sugar concentration, high turgor) to sink (low sugar concentration, low turgor). A single source leaf can supply multiple sinks simultaneously. (4) Why not mature lower leaves — mature leaves are themselves sources (they export sugars), so they do not import from other leaves. This explains why no 14C appears in mature leaves below the labeled leaf. (5) The Munch pressure-flow hypothesis explains the mechanism: active loading of sugars into phloem at sources creates high osmotic pressure, while active unloading at sinks creates low pressure. The resulting pressure gradient drives mass flow from source to sink. Xylem transport (A) is unidirectional root-to-shoot. Not all tissues photosynthesize (B). 14C is not toxic at tracer levels (D).

questions.question: Modified stems include rhizomes, stolons, tubers, and bulbs. Which correctly identifies a tuber as a modified stem rather than a modified root?
options: Tubers (like potatoes) are modified stems because they possess axillary buds ('eyes') arranged in a spiral pattern corresponding to nodes, have an internal structure with pith, vascular bundles, and cortex similar to stems, and develop from swollen stolons (underground stems) — true root tubers (like sweet potatoes) lack these stem characteristics
Tubers are always above ground
Tubers are modified flowers
All underground plant structures are roots
questions.explanation: Distinguishing modified stems from modified roots requires identifying the diagnostic features of each organ type: (1) Potato tubers (stem tubers) — modified stems because they possess: (a) 'Eyes' — these are axillary buds with a scale leaf scar. Each eye can sprout a new shoot, just as a stem axillary bud would. (b) Nodal arrangement — eyes are arranged in a spiral pattern corresponding to the phyllotactic pattern of a stem. (c) Internal stem anatomy — cross-sections show an outer periderm (bark), cortex, ring of vascular bundles (in some cases), pith, and starch-filled parenchyma — all consistent with stem structure. (d) Developmental origin — potato tubers develop from the swelling of stolons (horizontal underground stems). (2) Sweet potato (root tubers) — modified adventitious roots because they: (a) Lack 'eyes' (no axillary buds). (b) Show root-type vascular anatomy (central stele with xylem star). (c) Develop from adventitious roots that swell with stored starch. (d) Can regenerate shoots, but from adventitious buds formed de novo, not from pre-existing axillary buds. (3) Other modified stems: rhizomes (horizontal underground stems, like ginger, iris), stolons (horizontal above-ground runners, like strawberry), and bulbs (compressed stems with fleshy leaf bases, like onion). Tubers can be underground (B is wrong). Tubers are not flowers (C). Not all underground structures are roots (D) — many are modified stems.

questions.question: Mycorrhizal associations between plant roots and fungi are present in approximately 80-90% of plant species. The mutualistic benefit to the plant host is primarily:
options: Enhanced mineral nutrition, particularly phosphorus — mycorrhizal fungal hyphae extend far beyond the root depletion zone, accessing phosphorus (and other immobile nutrients) from a much larger soil volume than roots alone could exploit, while the fungus receives photosynthetically fixed carbon (sugars) from the plant
Protection from herbivorous mammals
Production of flowers and seeds
Nitrogen fixation (converting N2 to NH3)
questions.explanation: Mycorrhizal associations are among the most important symbioses in terrestrial ecosystems: (1) Types — (a) Arbuscular mycorrhizae (AM) — Glomeromycota fungi that penetrate root cortical cells and form arbuscules (highly branched structures for nutrient exchange). Found in ~80% of plant species. (b) Ectomycorrhizae (ECM) — Basidiomycota and Ascomycota fungi that form a sheath around root tips and grow between cortical cells (Hartig net) without penetrating them. Found in many trees (pines, oaks, birches). (2) Phosphorus uptake — the primary benefit to plants: (a) Phosphorus is immobile in soil — it diffuses very slowly through soil water. Roots rapidly deplete P from the immediately surrounding soil, creating a depletion zone. (b) Mycorrhizal hyphae are much thinner than roots (2-10 um diameter vs. 200+ um for root hairs) and extend centimeters to meters beyond the root depletion zone, accessing P from a vastly larger soil volume. (c) Fungal hyphae express phosphate transporters and phosphatases that efficiently scavenge P from soil. (d) P is transported along hyphae to the root in the form of polyphosphate. (3) Carbon exchange — the plant provides 10-20% of its photosynthetically fixed carbon to the fungus as sugars (primarily hexoses in AM, sucrose in some ECM). (4) Additional benefits — improved water uptake, enhanced resistance to pathogens, and access to other nutrients (N, Zn, Cu). Herbivore protection (B) is not the primary benefit. Flowers and seeds (C) are not produced by fungi. Nitrogen fixation (D) is performed by rhizobia bacteria, not mycorrhizal fungi (though some mycorrhizae do enhance N uptake).

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether cell fate in the root meristem is determined by cell lineage (ancestry) or by positional information (signals from neighboring cells). The BEST experimental approach is:
options: Laser ablation of specific cells in the root meristem and observation of whether neighboring cells change fate to replace the ablated cells — if positional information determines fate, neighbors should adopt the fate appropriate to their new position (replacing the lost cell type); if lineage determines fate, neighbors should NOT change fate regardless of their new position
Measuring the total root length
Counting the number of root hairs
Weighing the root system
questions.explanation: Laser ablation is the definitive experimental approach for testing lineage vs. position models of cell fate determination: (1) Experimental design — a focused UV or IR laser beam is used to kill (ablate) specific individual cells in the root meristem. The development of neighboring cells is then observed over time. (2) Position model prediction — if positional information determines cell fate, removing a cell changes the signaling environment of its neighbors. Neighbors should respond to their new positional context and adopt the fate of the removed cell. For example, if a cortex initial is ablated, an adjacent endodermis initial might shift position and adopt cortex identity. (3) Lineage model prediction — if lineage determines cell fate, cells inherit their identity from their mother cell regardless of position. Ablating a neighbor should NOT cause cells to change fate — they should continue with their lineage-determined identity. (4) Results in plants — Van den Berg et al. (1995) performed laser ablation experiments in Arabidopsis roots and found that: when quiescent center cells were ablated, adjacent initial cells lost their stem cell identity and began differentiating; when cortex/endodermis initials were ablated, neighboring cells shifted to fill the position and adopted the appropriate fate. These results strongly support the positional information model — cell fate in roots is determined by position, not lineage. (5) Mechanism — positional signals include SHR/SCR transcription factor movement, auxin gradients, and other intercellular signals.

questions.question: Transfer cells are specialized parenchyma cells found at sites of intensive solute transfer (e.g., phloem loading sites, xylem-phloem transfer points). They are characterized by:
options: Smooth, thin cell walls with no special features
Complete absence of plasma membrane
No connection to any vascular tissue

Extensive cell wall ingrowths that dramatically increase the surface area of the plasma membrane, amplifying the capacity for membrane transport proteins (H+-ATPases, sucrose transporters) to actively load or unload solutes — the wall ingrowths can increase membrane surface area by 2-20 fold
questions.explanation: Transfer cells are a remarkable example of structural specialization for transport function: (1) Wall ingrowths — the hallmark feature is extensive invaginations (ingrowths) of the cell wall, which push inward into the cell. The plasma membrane closely follows these ingrowths, creating a highly convoluted membrane surface. This can increase the effective membrane surface area by 2-20 fold compared to a cell with smooth walls. (2) Transport amplification — the enlarged membrane surface accommodates a higher density of transport proteins: (a) H+-ATPases — proton pumps that generate the electrochemical gradient driving secondary active transport. (b) Sucrose/H+ cotransporters — in phloem companion cells (transfer cells), these actively load sucrose from the apoplast into the phloem. (c) Amino acid transporters, ion channels, and other carriers. (3) Locations — transfer cells are found at strategic points where high-throughput solute transfer is needed: (a) Companion cells in minor veins of leaves that actively load sucrose for phloem export. (b) Endosperm transfer cells in cereal grains that import nutrients from the maternal tissue. (c) Haustoria of parasitic plants. (d) Root nodule transfer cells at the plant-Rhizobium interface. (4) Development — wall ingrowth formation requires localized cell wall deposition guided by the cytoskeleton, and is induced by signals indicating high transport demand.

questions.question: Adventitious roots differ from lateral roots in their origin. Adventitious roots arise from:
options: Stems, leaves, or other non-root tissues — they originate from parenchyma or other cells outside the root system, often in response to wounding, hormonal signals (particularly auxin), or environmental stress such as flooding, and form the basis of the fibrous root system in monocots
The root cap exclusively
The endodermis of existing roots
Seeds during germination only
questions.explanation: Adventitious roots are distinguished from lateral roots by their site of origin: (1) Lateral roots — originate from the pericycle of existing roots (endogenous origin from within the root system). They are a normal part of primary root system development. (2) Adventitious roots — originate from non-root tissues: (a) Stems — many plants produce adventitious roots from stem nodes (e.g., corn prop roots, ivy climbing roots, willow cuttings). (b) Leaves — some plants (like Kalanchoe/Bryophyllum) produce adventitious roots from leaf margins. (c) Callus tissue — wound sites can produce adventitious roots after callus formation. (3) Hormonal control — auxin is the primary hormone promoting adventitious root formation. High auxin/low cytokinin ratios favor rooting. This is the basis of vegetative propagation: dipping stem cuttings in auxin (IBA, NAA) promotes adventitious root formation. (4) Monocot fibrous root system — in monocots (grasses, cereals), the primary root from the radicle is short-lived. The adult root system consists entirely of adventitious roots arising from the stem base and nodes, creating the characteristic fibrous root system. (5) Environmental responses — flooding induces adventitious root formation in many species (mediated by ethylene accumulated in waterlogged tissues), replacing oxygen-starved roots with new roots that can function in the flooded environment. Adventitious roots do not originate from the root cap (B), endodermis (C), or only during germination (D).

questions.question: The orientation of cellulose microfibrils in the cell wall determines the direction of cell expansion. Cellulose microfibrils oriented transversely (perpendicular to the long axis) allow the cell to:
options: Expand equally in all directions (isodiametric growth)

Elongate along its long axis, because the transversely oriented microfibrils resist radial (lateral) expansion (like hoops on a barrel) while permitting longitudinal expansion driven by turgor pressure — this is why cortical microtubules, which guide cellulose synthase complexes, determine the axis of cell growth
Shrink and lose water
Only divide without expanding
questions.explanation: The relationship between cellulose microfibril orientation and cell expansion direction is one of the most elegant principles in plant cell biology, often called the 'multinet growth' model: (1) Hoop reinforcement — transversely oriented cellulose microfibrils act like hoops around a barrel. They resist expansion in the direction they wrap around (radially) but allow expansion perpendicular to their orientation (longitudinally). (2) Turgor-driven expansion — turgor pressure pushes equally in all directions against the cell wall. The wall yields preferentially in the direction of least resistance — perpendicular to the microfibril orientation. With transverse microfibrils, cells elongate longitudinally. (3) Microtubule guidance — cortical microtubules (located just inside the plasma membrane) serve as tracks that guide the movement of cellulose synthase (CESA) complexes in the plasma membrane. CESA complexes are rosette-shaped protein complexes that synthesize cellulose while moving in the plasma membrane, laying down microfibrils in the same orientation as the underlying microtubules. (4) Experimental evidence — disrupting microtubules with colchicine or oryzalin causes cells to expand isodiametrically (equally in all directions) because microfibrils are deposited randomly. This confirms that microtubule-guided microfibril orientation determines expansion direction. (5) Guard cell example — guard cells have radially oriented microfibrils, so when turgor increases, they expand longitudinally (along the curved guard cell), causing them to bow outward and open the stomatal pore.

questions.question: In Arabidopsis, the WUSCHEL (WUS) gene encodes a homeodomain transcription factor that maintains the stem cell population in the shoot apical meristem. Which region of the SAM expresses WUS?
options: The L1 layer (tunica) where epidermal cells differentiate
The peripheral zone where lateral organ primordia initiate
The rib meristem zone where stem tissue differentiates

The organizing center (OC), a small group of cells beneath the central zone — WUS protein moves into the overlying central zone stem cells via plasmodesmata, where it activates CLAVATA3 (CLV3), a secreted peptide that in turn signals back to repress WUS expression through the CLV1/CLV2 receptor kinase pathway, creating a negative feedback loop that maintains a stable stem cell population
questions.explanation: The WUS-CLV feedback loop is a cornerstone of shoot apical meristem regulation and is frequently tested in biology olympiads: (1) WUS expression domain — WUS is expressed specifically in the organizing center (OC), a small cluster of cells located beneath the central zone (CZ) of the SAM. The OC is functionally analogous to the 'organizer' in animal development. (2) Non-cell-autonomous action — WUS protein (a homeodomain transcription factor) moves from the OC into the overlying central zone stem cells through plasmodesmata. In these cells, WUS acts as a transcriptional regulator that maintains stem cell identity and prevents differentiation. (3) CLV3 induction — in the central zone cells, WUS activates transcription of CLAVATA3 (CLV3), which encodes a small secreted CLE (CLAVATA3/ESR-related) peptide. CLV3 peptide diffuses and binds to receptor complexes containing CLV1 (a leucine-rich repeat receptor kinase) and CLV2 in the OC cells. (4) Negative feedback — CLV1/CLV2 signaling represses WUS transcription, limiting the size of the OC and preventing overproliferation of stem cells. (5) Homeostasis — if stem cells are lost, CLV3 levels decrease, WUS repression is relieved, WUS increases, and new stem cells are specified. Conversely, excess stem cells produce excess CLV3, which represses WUS and reduces stem cell production. This elegant feedback creates a self-correcting homeostatic mechanism. WUS is not expressed in the L1 layer (A), peripheral zone (B), or rib meristem (C).

questions.question: Lateral roots in eudicots originate from which tissue layer, and by what developmental process?
options: The cortex, by cell expansion and outward bulging
The epidermis, by dedifferentiation of trichoblasts
The endodermis, by asymmetric cell division near the Casparian strip

The pericycle, by cell divisions that are initiated opposite the xylem poles — these divisions produce a lateral root primordium that grows through the cortex and epidermis; because the origin is internal (endogenous), lateral roots must physically push through overlying tissues, which is facilitated by auxin-regulated cell wall loosening enzymes
questions.explanation: Lateral root formation is one of the best-studied examples of organogenesis from differentiated tissue: (1) Pericycle origin — lateral roots originate from pericycle cells, specifically from founder cells located opposite the protoxylem poles. The pericycle is the outermost layer of the vascular cylinder (stele), just inside the endodermis. (2) Founder cell specification — not all pericycle cells become lateral root founders. Auxin accumulation, mediated by polar auxin transport, specifies particular pericycle cells as founders. The transcription factors LBD16/LBD29 (LATERAL ORGAN BOUNDARIES-DOMAIN) are auxin-responsive genes critical for this specification. (3) Endogenous origin — because lateral roots form deep within the root (at the pericycle), they must grow outward through the endodermis, cortex, and epidermis. This is called endogenous origin, in contrast to the exogenous origin of leaves and axillary buds from superficial layers. (4) Tissue penetration — as the lateral root primordium grows outward, it must mechanically push through overlying cell layers. This is facilitated by secretion of cell wall-degrading enzymes (cellulases, pectinases) by the primordium tip and by programmed cell separation in the overlying tissues. Auxin from the primordium triggers expression of these enzymes in cortical and epidermal cells ahead of the growing primordium. (5) Xylem pole position — lateral roots form preferentially at positions opposite protoxylem poles, not phloem poles, likely due to patterns of auxin accumulation related to the vascular architecture. The cortex (A), epidermis (B), and endodermis (C) do not give rise to lateral roots.

questions.question: A researcher measures the concentration of IAA (auxin) along a longitudinal transect of a root tip: the quiescent center shows the highest concentration, with a steep gradient decreasing toward the elongation zone. When the researcher applies NPA (an auxin transport inhibitor), root growth becomes disorganized and lateral root formation ceases. What does this experiment most directly demonstrate?
options: Auxin is synthesized only in leaves and transported downward
The quiescent center functions solely as a physical barrier

Auxin acts as a morphogen whose graded distribution, maintained by polar auxin transport, is essential for root patterning and organogenesis — the auxin maximum at the quiescent center organizes the root stem cell niche, and disruption of this gradient by NPA abolishes the positional information required for normal root development
Cytokinin is the primary hormone controlling root architecture
questions.explanation: This experiment illustrates the concept of auxin as a morphogen in root development: (1) Auxin maximum — the quiescent center (QC) and surrounding stem cells (the root stem cell niche) maintain the highest auxin concentration in the root. This auxin maximum is critical for maintaining stem cell identity and QC function. (2) Polar auxin transport (PAT) — the auxin gradient is established and maintained by directional transport mediated by PIN proteins (PIN-FORMED efflux carriers) and AUX1/LAX influx carriers. PIN proteins are asymmetrically localized on specific cell faces, creating directional auxin flow. In roots, PIN1 and PIN2 create an 'auxin reflux loop': acropetal transport through the stele to the root tip, then basipetal transport through the epidermis. (3) NPA experiment — NPA (1-N-naphthylphthalamic acid) inhibits auxin efflux by blocking PIN protein function. When PAT is disrupted, the auxin gradient collapses, and root organization is lost because cells no longer receive positional information from the auxin concentration gradient. (4) Morphogen concept — like morphogens in animal development (e.g., Bicoid in Drosophila), auxin provides concentration-dependent positional information. Different auxin concentrations activate different transcriptional programs through the TIR1/AFB auxin receptor pathway and Aux/IAA-ARF transcription factor modules. (5) Lateral root formation — lateral root primordia are initiated by local auxin accumulation in pericycle cells. Without proper PAT, these local maxima cannot form, explaining why NPA blocks lateral root formation. Auxin is not synthesized only in leaves (A), the QC is not merely a physical barrier (B), and cytokinin opposes rather than drives root growth (D).

questions.question: In the root apical meristem, the quiescent center (QC) is a group of cells that divide rarely. Despite their mitotic inactivity, QC cells are essential for root growth because they:
options: Provide the structural support that holds the root cap in place
Serve as a reservoir of starch granules for gravitropism

Function as an organizing center that maintains surrounding stem (initial) cells in an undifferentiated state through short-range signaling — laser ablation of QC cells causes adjacent initials to differentiate, demonstrating the QC's role as a stem cell niche organizer
Secrete mucilage that lubricates root penetration through soil
questions.explanation: The quiescent center is one of the most elegant examples of a stem cell niche in plants: (1) Low mitotic rate — QC cells divide much less frequently than surrounding cells (cell cycle of 2-3 weeks vs. 12-24 hours for active initials). This was first demonstrated by Clowes (1956) using tritiated thymidine autoradiography, which showed a central region of the root tip with very low DNA synthesis. (2) Stem cell maintenance — despite their own inactivity, QC cells are essential for maintaining the 'stemness' of surrounding initial cells. The QC sends short-range signals that prevent the adjacent initials from differentiating. (3) Laser ablation evidence — when Van den Berg et al. (1997) used laser ablation to destroy individual QC cells in Arabidopsis roots, the adjacent initial cells lost their stem cell identity and began to differentiate. When QC cells were replaced (by regeneration from surrounding cells), stem cell identity was restored in adjacent cells. This is direct evidence that the QC functions as an organizing center. (4) Molecular mechanisms — the QC expresses WOX5 (WUSCHEL-RELATED HOMEOBOX 5), a transcription factor analogous to WUS in the shoot. WOX5 moves from QC cells to adjacent columella initials, suppressing their differentiation. Loss of WOX5 causes columella initials to differentiate prematurely, similar to QC ablation. (5) Auxin role — the auxin maximum at the QC (maintained by polar auxin transport via PIN proteins) is critical for QC identity. PLT (PLETHORA) transcription factors, induced by high auxin levels, specify and maintain QC and stem cell identity. The QC is not merely structural support (A), starch reservoir (B), or mucilage source (D).

questions.question:
Match the following plant tissue types with their defining characteristics:
(P) Collenchyma
(Q) Sclerenchyma
(R) Parenchyma
(S) Meristematic tissue

1. Thick secondary walls impregnated with lignin; dead at functional maturity
2. Unevenly thickened primary walls rich in pectin; provides flexible mechanical support; alive at maturity
3. Thin primary walls; versatile cells capable of photosynthesis, storage, and secretion; totipotent
4. Cells with dense cytoplasm, small vacuoles, and no secondary walls; actively dividing
questions.explanation: This matching tests fundamental knowledge of plant tissue types: (1) Collenchyma (P-2) — collenchyma cells have unevenly (irregularly) thickened primary cell walls. The thickening is rich in pectin and hemicellulose (NOT lignin). Key features: alive at functional maturity, provides flexible support to growing organs (young stems, petioles, leaf veins). The uneven thickening can be angular (thickened at corners, as in celery petioles), lamellar (thickened on tangential walls), or lacunar (thickened facing intercellular spaces). (2) Sclerenchyma (Q-1) — sclerenchyma cells have thick secondary walls heavily impregnated with lignin. They are dead at functional maturity (the protoplast degenerates after the secondary wall is complete). Two main types: fibers (long, slender cells providing tensile strength — hemp, flax, jute) and sclereids (shorter cells with various shapes — stone cells in pear fruit, seed coats). (3) Parenchyma (R-3) — parenchyma cells are the most common and versatile plant cells. They have thin, flexible primary walls, large central vacuoles, and perform diverse functions: photosynthesis (chlorenchyma), storage (starch in potato tubers, fats in seeds), secretion, and wound healing. They retain totipotency — the ability to dedifferentiate and resume cell division — which is the basis for plant tissue culture and regeneration. (4) Meristematic tissue (S-4) — meristematic cells are characterized by dense cytoplasm (high nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio), numerous small vacuoles (not one large central vacuole), lack of secondary walls, and active cell division. They are found in SAM, RAM, and lateral meristems.

questions.question: A researcher hypothesizes that the vascular cambium produces more secondary xylem than secondary phloem because xylem-side daughter cells undergo more rounds of division before differentiation. To test this, the researcher should:
options: Count the total number of vessels in a cross-section
Measure the total wood diameter and assume uniform cell size

Pulse-label dividing cambial cells with EdU (a thymidine analog), then track labeled cell lineages at intervals using confocal microscopy — if xylem-side derivatives divide more times before terminal differentiation, labeled clones on the xylem side should contain more cells than phloem-side clones after the same time period
Remove all secondary phloem and observe whether xylem production increases
questions.explanation: This experiment tests the asymmetric production of secondary xylem vs. phloem by the vascular cambium: (1) The phenomenon — in most woody plants, the vascular cambium produces significantly more secondary xylem (wood) inward than secondary phloem (inner bark) outward. This asymmetry accounts for the fact that tree trunks are mostly wood with a relatively thin layer of bark. (2) The hypothesis — one explanation is that xylem mother cells (derivatives on the inner side of the cambium) undergo more rounds of cell division before terminal differentiation than do phloem mother cells (outer derivatives). (3) EdU pulse-chase approach — EdU (5-ethynyl-2'-deoxyuridine) is a thymidine analog that incorporates into DNA during S-phase. By pulse-labeling dividing cells, the researcher can track clonal lineages. After a chase period, the number of cells in each labeled clone indicates how many divisions occurred. If xylem-side clones contain more cells than phloem-side clones, this supports the hypothesis of differential division frequency. (4) Confocal microscopy — allows optical sectioning to track labeled cells through tissue without physical sectioning artifacts, and can be combined with cell-type-specific markers to confirm xylem vs. phloem identity. (5) Why other options fail — counting vessels (A) doesn't address division frequency; measuring diameter (B) confounds cell size with cell number; removing phloem (C) tests a different question about feedback regulation. The EdU lineage-tracing approach directly tests the mechanistic hypothesis about differential division rates.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the arrangement of vascular bundles in monocot stems compared to eudicot stems?
options: Monocot stems have vascular bundles arranged in a ring around a central pith, with a vascular cambium between xylem and phloem
Both monocots and eudicots have identical vascular bundle arrangements
Eudicot stems have scattered vascular bundles throughout ground tissue

Monocot stems have vascular bundles scattered throughout the ground tissue without a clear ring arrangement, and they typically lack a vascular cambium — this scattered arrangement means monocots generally cannot produce secondary growth, which is why palm trees increase trunk diameter by primary thickening meristems rather than by true wood production
questions.explanation: The arrangement of vascular bundles is one of the key anatomical differences between monocots and eudicots: (1) Monocot stems — vascular bundles are scattered (atactostele arrangement) throughout the ground tissue. Each bundle is a collateral bundle with xylem toward the center and phloem toward the outside, surrounded by a bundle sheath of sclerenchyma. Critically, there is no vascular cambium between the xylem and phloem within each bundle, and no interfascicular cambium between bundles. (2) Eudicot stems — vascular bundles are arranged in a ring (eustele arrangement) around a central pith. Each bundle has a fascicular cambium between xylem and phloem, and interfascicular cambium connects the fascicular cambia to form a complete vascular cambium ring. This allows secondary growth. (3) Secondary growth implications — because monocots lack a vascular cambium, they cannot produce true secondary xylem and phloem (wood and inner bark). Monocot stems achieve their final diameter through primary growth only. (4) Palm trunks — palms (monocots) can grow very tall but their trunks are not true wood. They achieve thickness through a primary thickening meristem (PTM) located below the SAM, which adds ground tissue and vascular bundles during primary growth. Some older palm trunks also undergo diffuse secondary growth (expansion of existing parenchyma cells). (5) Exceptions — a few monocots (Dracaena, Yucca) have a special secondary thickening meristem that produces vascular bundles and parenchyma, but this is not homologous to the eudicot vascular cambium. Options A (ring with cambium describes eudicots), B (they differ), and C (eudicots have ring arrangement) are all incorrect.

questions.question: The Casparian strip in the endodermis is composed primarily of:
options: Cellulose microfibrils arranged in a helical pattern
Cutin deposited on the outer tangential walls

Suberin and lignin deposited in the radial and transverse walls of endodermal cells — this hydrophobic barrier forces water and dissolved minerals to pass through the symplast (crossing the plasma membrane), allowing the endodermis to function as a selective filter controlling mineral uptake into the vascular cylinder
Callose plugs in the sieve plate regions
questions.explanation: The Casparian strip is a defining feature of the root endodermis and is critical for selective mineral uptake: (1) Chemical composition — the Casparian strip is composed of suberin (a waxy, hydrophobic polyester) and lignin deposited in the radial (anticlinal) and transverse walls of endodermal cells. These deposits form a continuous band (the 'strip') that encircles each endodermal cell like a belt or gasket. (2) Location — the strip is specifically in the radial and transverse cell walls, NOT in the tangential (inner and outer periclinal) walls. This means the strip blocks the apoplastic pathway between endodermal cells while still allowing symplastic movement through the tangential walls. (3) Functional significance — water and dissolved minerals traveling through the root via the apoplast (through cell walls and intercellular spaces) encounter the hydrophobic Casparian strip at the endodermis. They cannot pass through the suberized/lignified walls. Instead, they must cross the plasma membrane of an endodermal cell to enter the symplast. This forced membrane crossing allows the endodermis to selectively control which minerals enter the stele (vascular cylinder) and at what rate, using membrane transport proteins (channels and carriers). (4) Suberin lamellae — in older parts of the root, endodermal cells may deposit additional suberin lamellae on all wall surfaces (State II endodermis), further restricting apoplastic transport. Some endodermal cells (passage cells, often near protoxylem poles) remain in State I with only the Casparian strip, providing continued pathways for selective uptake. Cellulose microfibrils (A), cutin (B), and callose (D) are not components of the Casparian strip.

questions.question: A dendrologist examines a cross-section of a temperate hardwood tree and observes alternating bands of large-diameter vessels followed by small-diameter vessels and fibers. The large vessels appear to form in early spring. This pattern is characteristic of:
options: Diffuse-porous wood, where vessels of similar size are distributed evenly throughout each growth ring

Ring-porous wood, where large earlywood (springwood) vessels are followed by small latewood (summerwood) vessels — this pattern reflects seasonal variation in cambial activity: rapid early-season growth produces wide vessels for efficient water transport, while later growth emphasizes mechanical support through narrow vessels and fibers
Softwood (conifer) anatomy with tracheids only
Heartwood formation with tyloses blocking all vessels
questions.explanation: Ring-porous vs. diffuse-porous wood anatomy is an important concept in plant biology and dendrology: (1) Ring-porous wood — characterized by a distinct zone of large-diameter vessels (earlywood/springwood) at the beginning of each annual ring, followed by a zone of smaller vessels and fibers (latewood/summerwood). Examples: oak (Quercus), ash (Fraxinus), elm (Ulmus), black walnut (Juglans nigra). The large earlywood vessels can be visible to the naked eye. (2) Seasonal pattern — in ring-porous species, the vascular cambium reactivates in spring and immediately produces wide vessels. These large vessels are critical for early-season water transport when transpiration demand increases as leaves emerge. As the growing season progresses, the cambium shifts to producing narrower vessels, fibers (for mechanical support), and wood parenchyma. (3) Diffuse-porous wood (A) — vessels are of relatively uniform size throughout the growth ring, distributed evenly rather than in distinct zones. Examples: maple (Acer), birch (Betula), poplar (Populus). (4) Ecological significance — ring-porous species tend to be more vulnerable to spring freezes because their large earlywood vessels are prone to cavitation (air embolism). They rely on producing new vessels each spring rather than refilling old ones. Diffuse-porous species are often more freeze-tolerant. (5) Conifers (C) — softwoods lack vessels entirely; they conduct water through tracheids only. Tyloses (D) are balloon-like outgrowths of parenchyma cells into vessel lumens, associated with heartwood formation, not the described pattern.

questions.question: Trichomes are epidermal appendages that serve diverse functions. Which of the following is NOT a documented function of trichomes in plants?
options: Reducing water loss by creating a boundary layer of still air near the leaf surface
Deterring herbivory through physical (spines, hooks) or chemical (toxic secretions) means
Conducting water and minerals upward from roots to leaves through their hollow central lumen
Absorbing water and nutrients, as in the root hairs (which are specialized trichomes) and the peltate trichomes of Tillandsia (air plants)
questions.explanation: Trichomes are remarkably diverse epidermal appendages, but they do not function as long-distance water-conducting elements: (1) Boundary layer (A — TRUE function) — dense trichome coverage (pubescence) on leaf surfaces creates a boundary layer of still, humid air that reduces transpiration. This is especially important in plants adapted to dry or windy environments. Desert plants and alpine plants often have dense trichome coverage. (2) Herbivore defense (B — TRUE function) — trichomes provide multiple defense mechanisms: simple physical barriers (dense hairs impeding insect movement), hooked trichomes (trapping small insects, as in Phaseolus), stinging trichomes (Urtica/nettle — silica tip breaks off to inject histamine, acetylcholine, and formic acid), and glandular trichomes (secreting toxic or sticky compounds — terpenes in tomato, cannabinoids in Cannabis). (3) Water and nutrient absorption (D — TRUE function) — root hairs are tubular extensions of single epidermal cells (trichoblasts) that dramatically increase root surface area for water and mineral absorption. Additionally, Tillandsia species (bromeliads/air plants) have specialized peltate (shield-shaped) trichomes on their leaves that absorb water and dissolved minerals directly from rain and atmospheric moisture, enabling them to grow epiphytically without soil contact. (4) Long-distance water transport (C — FALSE, the correct answer) — trichomes are epidermal structures that do not have hollow lumens connected to the vascular system for long-distance transport. Water transport is performed by xylem vessels and tracheids, which are vascular tissue elements, not epidermal appendages. Trichomes may absorb water locally but do not conduct it over long distances.

questions.question: During secondary growth, the bark of a tree consists of all tissues external to the vascular cambium. Which component of bark is responsible for replacing the epidermis as the protective outer covering?
options: The cork cambium (phellogen), which produces cork (phellem) to the outside and phelloderm to the inside — together these three layers constitute the periderm, and successive periderms form as the stem expands, with the outermost layers becoming the rough outer bark composed of dead, suberized cork cells
Secondary phloem conducting sugars from source to sink
The cortex parenchyma that persists throughout the tree's life
Lenticels that cover the entire stem surface
questions.explanation: The periderm is the replacement protective tissue in plants undergoing secondary growth: (1) Periderm components — the periderm consists of three layers: (a) Cork cambium (phellogen) — a lateral meristem that arises from cortex parenchyma or, in later periderms, from secondary phloem parenchyma. (b) Cork (phellem) — produced to the outside by the cork cambium. Cork cells are dead at maturity, with walls impregnated with suberin (a hydrophobic fatty polyester). They form an impermeable barrier to water, gases, and pathogens. (c) Phelloderm — produced to the inside by the cork cambium. These are living parenchyma cells, typically just one to a few layers thick. (2) Epidermis replacement — as secondary growth increases stem diameter, the epidermis is stretched, torn, and eventually shed. The first periderm forms from cortex cells and takes over the protective function. (3) Successive periderms — as the stem continues to expand, the first periderm is also eventually split and shed. New periderms form progressively deeper in the stem, typically from secondary phloem parenchyma. (4) Outer bark (rhytidome) — the accumulation of successive dead periderms (and any tissues trapped between them) constitutes the outer bark or rhytidome. The texture and appearance of bark varies enormously among species depending on how periderms form and split. (5) Inner bark — the living secondary phloem constitutes the inner bark. Secondary phloem (B) conducts photosynthate but is not the protective covering. The cortex (C) is crushed and lost during secondary growth. Lenticels (D) are small porous areas for gas exchange, not the entire covering.

questions.question: In the ABC model of flower development (later extended to ABCE), what structures develop when only C-class genes (such as AGAMOUS) are expressed in a whorl?
options: Sepals
Petals
Stamens

Carpels — C-class gene expression alone specifies carpel identity in whorl 4; stamens require the overlapping expression of B-class + C-class genes in whorl 3, petals require A + B in whorl 2, and sepals require A-class alone in whorl 1
questions.explanation: The ABC model (Coen and Meyerowitz, 1991) is one of the most important models in plant developmental biology: (1) The model — three classes of homeotic genes (A, B, C) act in overlapping domains across the four floral whorls to specify organ identity: Whorl 1 (outermost): A alone → sepals; Whorl 2: A + B → petals; Whorl 3: B + C → stamens; Whorl 4 (innermost): C alone → carpels. (2) C-class genes — in Arabidopsis, the primary C-class gene is AGAMOUS (AG), a MADS-box transcription factor. When only AG is expressed (whorl 4, without B-class genes AP3/PI), it specifies carpel identity. (3) Mutual antagonism — A and C classes are mutually antagonistic: A-class genes repress C-class expression in whorls 1-2, and C-class genes repress A-class expression in whorls 3-4. If A-class function is lost (e.g., ap1 or ap2 mutants), C expands into all four whorls, producing carpels-stamens-stamens-carpels. If C is lost (ag mutant), A expands into all whorls, producing sepals-petals-petals-sepals (with indeterminate growth). (4) ABCE extension — the E-class genes (SEPALLATA1-4) are required in all whorls as co-factors. Without E-class function, all organs revert to leaf-like structures, supporting Goethe's hypothesis that floral organs are modified leaves. The 'quartet model' proposes that specific tetrameric MADS-box protein complexes (composed of A, B, C, E proteins in various combinations) determine organ identity. (5) Molecular basis — A, B, C, and E class genes all encode MADS-box transcription factors (except AP2, which is an AP2/ERF family member). Sepals (A), petals (B), and stamens (C) are each incorrect because they require different gene class combinations.

questions.question: Totipotency in plants refers to the ability of a single cell to develop into a complete organism. Which cell type best exemplifies totipotency in practical applications?
options: Mature sieve tube elements that have lost their nuclei

Parenchyma cells, which retain the ability to dedifferentiate and re-enter the cell cycle — this property underlies tissue culture (micropropagation), where explant parenchyma cells form callus, which can then regenerate shoots and roots under appropriate auxin:cytokinin ratios, enabling clonal propagation of thousands of genetically identical plants
Sclerenchyma fibers with thick lignified secondary walls
Dead cork cells of the outer bark
questions.explanation: Plant totipotency and tissue culture are fundamental concepts in plant biology and biotechnology: (1) Totipotency defined — the ability of a single differentiated cell to regenerate an entire organism. This was demonstrated by Steward (1958) using carrot phloem parenchyma cells cultured in coconut milk medium, which regenerated complete carrot plants. (2) Parenchyma cells — among differentiated plant cell types, parenchyma cells most readily exhibit totipotency because they retain their nucleus, have thin primary walls without extensive lignification, maintain the full complement of genes, and can be induced to dedifferentiate (re-enter the cell cycle). (3) Tissue culture process — (a) Explant tissue containing parenchyma cells is placed on sterile medium. (b) Cells dedifferentiate and divide to form an undifferentiated mass called callus. (c) Callus cells can be directed to regenerate organs by manipulating the auxin:cytokinin ratio in the medium: high auxin:low cytokinin favors root formation; low auxin:high cytokinin favors shoot formation (Skoog-Miller ratio). (d) Complete plantlets are transferred to soil for acclimatization. (4) Applications — micropropagation for clonal propagation, pathogen-free plant production (meristem culture), genetic transformation (Agrobacterium-mediated), somatic hybridization (protoplast fusion), and conservation of endangered species. (5) Why other options are wrong — sieve tube elements (A) lack nuclei and cannot divide; sclerenchyma fibers (C) are dead or have heavily lignified walls that prevent dedifferentiation; cork cells (D) are dead.

questions.question: A plant physiologist stains root cross-sections with berberine-aniline blue (which fluoresces at Casparian strips) and observes that in the mature endodermis, certain cells opposite the protoxylem poles lack fluorescent Casparian strips on their inner tangential walls. These cells are termed:
options: Transfusion cells found only in gymnosperm leaves

Passage cells — they remain in the primary (State I) endodermal condition with only Casparian strips in their radial walls, while surrounding endodermal cells develop thick suberin lamellae on all walls (State II) or tertiary wall thickenings (State III), allowing passage cells to serve as selective entry points for water and minerals into the stele in older root regions
Guard cells forming stomata in the endodermis
Companion cells associated with phloem sieve tubes
questions.explanation: Passage cells are an important specialization within the root endodermis: (1) Endodermal development stages — endodermal cells progress through developmental states as the root matures: State I — Casparian strips in radial and transverse walls only (all young endodermal cells start here). State II — suberin lamellae deposited on all wall surfaces (inner tangential, outer tangential, and over the Casparian strips), creating an almost completely impermeable barrier. State III (in some species) — additional cellulose thickening (sometimes lignified) on the inner tangential wall, forming a U-shaped thickening pattern. (2) Passage cells — some endodermal cells, typically those located opposite the protoxylem poles, remain in State I even as surrounding cells progress to States II and III. These cells retain only their Casparian strips without additional suberin lamellae, making them relatively more permeable. (3) Functional significance — in older root regions where most endodermal cells are heavily suberized, passage cells provide the primary route for water and mineral uptake from the cortex into the stele. They function as selective entry points because water and minerals still must cross the plasma membrane (due to the Casparian strip blocking the apoplast) but can pass more easily through the thinner walls. (4) Position — passage cells are characteristically located opposite protoxylem poles, suggesting a developmental relationship between the patterning of vascular tissues and endodermal differentiation. (5) Berberine-aniline blue staining — this fluorescent stain specifically highlights suberin and lignin deposits. The absence of fluorescence on inner tangential walls identifies cells that have not deposited suberin lamellae (passage cells in State I). Transfusion cells (A), guard cells (C), and companion cells (D) are different cell types entirely.

questions.question: The transition from vegetative to reproductive development in Arabidopsis involves the floral meristem identity gene LEAFY (LFY). What is the primary molecular function of LFY?
options: LFY is a kinase that phosphorylates floral organ identity proteins

LFY is a transcription factor that activates floral homeotic genes (ABC genes) — it directly binds to the promoters of AP1 (A-class), AP3 (B-class), and AGAMOUS (C-class) genes to initiate the floral development program, converting lateral meristems from vegetative (leaf-producing) to reproductive (flower-producing) identity
LFY is a mobile RNA signal that moves from roots to shoots
LFY is a membrane receptor that detects photoperiod signals
questions.explanation: LEAFY (LFY) is a master regulator of the transition from vegetative to reproductive development: (1) Transcription factor function — LFY encodes a plant-specific transcription factor that directly binds to DNA regulatory elements in the promoters of floral homeotic genes. Crystal structure studies show LFY forms a dimer and binds a pseudo-palindromic DNA sequence. (2) Direct targets — LFY directly activates: AP1/CAULIFLOWER (A-class genes for meristem and sepal identity), AP3/PI (B-class genes for petal and stamen identity), and AGAMOUS (C-class gene for stamen and carpel identity). LFY activates AG in combination with the co-activator WUS. (3) Meristem identity switch — before LFY activation, lateral primordia on the inflorescence meristem develop as leaves or bracts. Once LFY is expressed at sufficient levels, lateral primordia are converted to floral meristems that produce flowers instead of vegetative structures. In lfy mutants, flowers are partially replaced by shoot-like structures with leaf-like organs. (4) Gradual accumulation — LFY expression increases gradually as the plant transitions to flowering, with complete conversion occurring when LFY levels exceed a threshold. This explains why the first lateral organs on an inflorescence may be intermediate between leaves and flowers (coflorescence or bract-like structures). (5) Integration of flowering signals — LFY expression is upregulated by multiple flowering pathway signals: photoperiod pathway (through CO/CONSTANS), vernalization pathway, gibberellin pathway, and autonomous pathway. This makes LFY a convergence point for diverse environmental and developmental signals. LFY is not a kinase (A), mobile RNA (C), or membrane receptor (D).

questions.question: Vessel elements in angiosperms are more efficient at water conduction than tracheids because:
options: Vessel elements have perforation plates at their end walls that allow free flow of water between cells — these open perforations eliminate much of the resistance to water flow, creating continuous tubes (vessels) that can be several meters long; tracheids rely on water passing through pit pairs in their lateral walls, which creates greater resistance
Vessel elements have thicker secondary walls than tracheids
Tracheids are dead cells while vessel elements are living
Vessel elements contain symplastic connections (plasmodesmata) for active water pumping
questions.explanation: The evolution of vessel elements was a major innovation in angiosperm water transport efficiency: (1) Perforation plates — the defining feature of vessel elements (compared to tracheids) is the presence of perforation plates at their end walls. Perforations are actual holes (complete removal of both primary and secondary wall material) that allow unobstructed water flow between vertically stacked vessel elements. Simple perforation plates have a single large opening; scalariform perforation plates have multiple parallel, ladder-like openings. (2) Vessels vs. tracheids — multiple vessel elements stacked end-to-end with perforation plates form a vessel, which functions as a continuous pipe. Water moves through vessels with much less resistance than through tracheids, where it must pass through pit membranes (thin primary wall material spanning pit pairs) between adjacent cells. (3) Quantitative comparison — the Hagen-Poiseuille equation shows that flow rate through a tube increases with the fourth power of the radius. Vessel elements are typically wider (up to 500 micrometers in some lianas and ring-porous trees) than tracheids (usually 10-25 micrometers). Combined with perforation plates, vessels can conduct water 4-100 times more efficiently than tracheids. (4) Both are dead — both vessel elements and tracheids are dead at functional maturity (C is wrong). Their protoplasts undergo programmed cell death during development, leaving hollow cells with lignified secondary walls. (5) No plasmodesmata — neither vessel elements nor tracheids have plasmodesmata or active pumping mechanisms (D is wrong). Water moves through xylem passively, driven by the transpiration-cohesion-tension mechanism. Wall thickness (B) is not the primary difference in conductance efficiency.

questions.question: To determine whether the phytochrome photoreceptor system controls the shade avoidance response (stem elongation under canopy shade), a researcher should:
options: Grow plants in complete darkness for their entire lifecycle
Apply saturating concentrations of gibberellin to all experimental plants

Compare wild-type plants to phytochrome-B (phyB) null mutants under high and low red:far-red (R:FR) ratio light conditions — if phyB mediates the shade avoidance response, wild-type plants should show increased stem elongation under low R:FR (simulating canopy shade), while phyB mutants should show constitutive elongation regardless of R:FR ratio, phenocopying a shaded wild-type plant even in full sunlight
Measure chlorophyll content in sun vs. shade leaves only
questions.explanation: The shade avoidance syndrome (SAS) is a classic example of photomorphogenesis mediated by phytochrome: (1) R:FR ratio sensing — green vegetation absorbs red light (660 nm) for photosynthesis but transmits/reflects far-red light (730 nm). Under a canopy, the ratio of red to far-red light (R:FR ratio) drops significantly. Plants detect this spectral change primarily through phytochrome B (phyB). (2) Phytochrome interconversion — phytochrome exists in two interconvertible forms: Pr (red-absorbing, inactive) and Pfr (far-red-absorbing, active). High R:FR converts phytochrome to the active Pfr form; low R:FR shifts the equilibrium toward inactive Pr. Under canopy shade (low R:FR), Pfr levels drop, triggering shade avoidance responses. (3) Shade avoidance responses — reduced Pfr leads to: rapid stem and petiole elongation (to grow above competitors), hyponastic (upward) leaf movement, reduced branching, accelerated flowering, reduced chlorophyll content, and increased apical dominance. (4) phyB mutant experiment — the proposed experiment uses the classical genetics approach of comparing loss-of-function mutants to wild type under different conditions. If phyB is the primary receptor: (a) Wild type in high R:FR = normal compact phenotype (high Pfr). (b) Wild type in low R:FR = elongated shade avoidance phenotype (low Pfr). (c) phyB mutant in high R:FR = elongated phenotype (constitutive shade avoidance because the receptor is absent). (d) phyB mutant in low R:FR = elongated (already maximally responding). The key prediction is that the phyB mutant constitutively phenocopies shaded wild type, confirming phyB as the shade sensor. Complete darkness (A), exogenous GA (B), and chlorophyll measurement alone (D) do not test the phytochrome hypothesis directly.

questions.question: Companion cells in the phloem are closely associated with sieve tube elements. What is the primary role of companion cells?
options: They provide mechanical support by developing thick secondary walls
They directly transport water from xylem to phloem

They provide metabolic support to enucleate sieve tube elements — companion cells retain their nucleus and full complement of organelles, and are connected to sieve tube elements through specialized plasmodesmata (pore-plasmodesmata); they supply ATP, proteins (including P-proteins), and mRNA to the sieve tube elements via these connections
They synthesize suberin for the Casparian strip
questions.explanation: The companion cell-sieve tube element complex is a functional unit in the phloem: (1) Developmental origin — companion cells and sieve tube elements arise from the same mother cell by an unequal division. The smaller daughter cell becomes the companion cell; the larger becomes the sieve tube element. This shared origin is reflected in their intimate functional relationship. (2) Sieve tube element specialization — during maturation, sieve tube elements undergo a remarkable selective autophagy: the nucleus degenerates, ribosomes are lost, the tonoplast breaks down (so there is no distinct vacuole), and most organelles are degraded. The remaining organelles (ER, mitochondria, plastids) and specialized P-proteins line the cell periphery. Sieve plates (modified end walls with sieve pores) connect adjacent sieve tube elements. (3) Companion cell support — because sieve tube elements lack nuclei and ribosomes, they depend on companion cells for proteins, ATP, and mRNA. Companion cells are metabolically very active, with dense cytoplasm, many mitochondria, and active ribosomes. (4) Pore-plasmodesmata connections — the interface between companion cells and sieve tube elements has specialized plasmodesmata called pore-plasmodesmata. On the companion cell side, they are branched (like typical plasmodesmata); on the sieve tube element side, they open into wider pores. These connections allow macromolecular traffic, including proteins and RNA. (5) Phloem loading — in many species, companion cells (specifically transfer cells or intermediary cells, depending on the loading mechanism) are responsible for loading sucrose from the apoplast into the SE-CC complex, driving pressure-flow transport. Companion cells do not provide mechanical support (A), transport water (B), or synthesize suberin (D).

questions.question: In determinate growth, the meristem is consumed by the production of a terminal structure. Which of the following is the best example of determinate growth in plants?
options: The vegetative shoot apical meristem continuously producing new leaves throughout the growing season
The root apical meristem growing indefinitely in length

A floral meristem producing the four whorls of flower organs (sepals, petals, stamens, carpels) and then ceasing all meristematic activity — AGAMOUS (C-class gene) is required not only for carpel identity but also for floral meristem determinacy; in ag mutants, the floral meristem becomes indeterminate, producing an indefinite number of whorls
The vascular cambium continuously producing secondary xylem and phloem
questions.explanation: Determinate vs. indeterminate growth is a fundamental concept in plant development: (1) Indeterminate growth — most plant meristems (SAM, RAM, vascular cambium, cork cambium) exhibit indeterminate growth: they are not consumed by the organs they produce and can continue growing indefinitely. The SAM produces leaves and axillary meristems while maintaining itself. This is why trees can grow for thousands of years. (2) Determinate growth — the floral meristem is the classic example of determinate growth. After producing the four whorls (sepals → petals → stamens → carpels), the floral meristem is entirely consumed. No meristematic cells remain — they have all differentiated into floral organ cells. (3) AGAMOUS and determinacy — the C-class gene AGAMOUS (AG) plays a dual role: it specifies carpel and stamen identity AND it promotes meristem determinacy. AG achieves determinacy by repressing WUSCHEL (WUS), the stem cell maintenance gene. Once AG is expressed and accumulates sufficiently, it shuts down WUS, causing stem cells to differentiate. (4) ag mutant phenotype — loss of AG function has two consequences: (a) C-class organ identity is lost (stamens → petals, carpels → sepals, due to A-class expansion). (b) The floral meristem becomes indeterminate, producing repeated whorls of sepals and petals indefinitely — a 'flower within a flower' phenotype. This demonstrates that AG is required for terminating meristem activity. (5) Molecular mechanism — AG directly represses WUS transcription through binding to WUS regulatory regions, and this repression requires the Polycomb group proteins (PcG) that establish repressive chromatin marks on the WUS locus. Vegetative SAM (A), RAM (B), and vascular cambium (D) all show indeterminate growth.

questions.question:
Match each type of secondary wall thickening pattern in protoxylem and metaxylem elements with its description:
(P) Annular
(Q) Helical (spiral)
(R) Scalariform
(S) Pitted

1. Secondary wall deposited as complete layer with pit areas; found in metaxylem vessels that are fully elongated
2. Secondary wall deposited as discrete rings; found in protoxylem that is still elongating
3. Secondary wall deposited as ladder-like parallel bars; transitional between extensible and non-extensible types
4. Secondary wall deposited as a continuous spiral band; found in protoxylem, allows some extension
questions.explanation: The pattern of secondary wall thickening in xylem elements correlates with whether the cell is still elongating or has reached final size: (1) Annular (P-2) — secondary wall deposited as a series of separate rings, like the rings of a trachea. This pattern occurs in protoxylem (the first-formed xylem), which differentiates while surrounding tissues are still elongating. The separate rings allow the cell to stretch — the rings are pulled apart like a spring as surrounding cells elongate, and the thin primary wall between rings can extend. (2) Helical/spiral (Q-4) — secondary wall deposited as a continuous spiral band (like a spring or slinky). Also found in protoxylem. Like annular thickening, the spiral can be stretched, accommodating longitudinal growth. Helical thickening provides somewhat more strength than annular while still permitting extension. (3) Scalariform (R-3) — secondary wall deposited as closely spaced horizontal bars, creating a ladder-like (scalariform = ladder-shaped) pattern with elongated pits between bars. This represents a transitional pattern between the extensible protoxylem types and the rigid metaxylem types. Found in late protoxylem or early metaxylem.
