(4) Pitted (S-1) — secondary wall deposited as a nearly complete layer, interrupted only by pit areas (regions where the secondary wall is absent, leaving only the primary wall and middle lamella). Found in metaxylem and secondary xylem vessels and tracheids that have reached their final length. Pitted vessels cannot extend longitudinally. Pits come in simple (uniform) and bordered (with overarching secondary wall) varieties. This developmental sequence (annular → helical → scalariform → pitted) reflects the transition from tissues still undergoing elongation growth to those that have reached mature size.

questions.question: The phenomenon of apical dominance — in which the main shoot tip inhibits the growth of lateral (axillary) buds — is primarily mediated by which hormonal interaction?
options: Ethylene produced by the roots inhibiting all shoot growth
Gibberellin from lateral buds suppressing the main shoot
Abscisic acid from the xylem sap inhibiting all meristems equally

Auxin produced by the shoot apex is transported basipetally and promotes the synthesis of strigolactones in the stem, which together inhibit axillary bud outgrowth — cytokinins produced in roots promote bud outgrowth, creating an auxin-strigolactone-cytokinin regulatory network that controls shoot branching architecture
questions.explanation: Apical dominance is a classic example of hormonal regulation of plant architecture and has been updated with modern molecular understanding: (1) Classical model — Thimann and Skoog (1933) demonstrated that auxin (IAA) from the shoot apex inhibits lateral bud outgrowth. Decapitation (removing the apex) relieves apical dominance, and applying auxin to the decapitated stump restores it. (2) Auxin does not act directly on buds — auxin concentration inside axillary buds does not increase when apical dominance is active. Instead, auxin acts indirectly by: (a) Promoting strigolactone biosynthesis — strigolactones (SLs) are synthesized from carotenoids via CCD7/CCD8 (MAX3/MAX4 in Arabidopsis) enzymes. Auxin from the apex upregulates these biosynthetic genes in the stem. SLs then directly inhibit axillary bud outgrowth. (b) Reducing cytokinin — auxin suppresses cytokinin biosynthesis in the stem. Cytokinins normally promote bud outgrowth, so reduced CK inhibits branching. (3) Strigolactone signaling — the SL receptor D14 and signaling component MAX2 (an F-box protein) target BRC1 (BRANCHED1), a TCP transcription factor that suppresses bud outgrowth. SLs stabilize BRC1 expression. In max mutants (deficient in SL biosynthesis or signaling), plants show excessive branching. (4) Cytokinin counter-regulation — cytokinins (produced mainly in root tips and transported via xylem) promote axillary bud outgrowth by activating cell division and antagonizing SL signaling. Application of cytokinin directly to axillary buds can override apical dominance. (5) Integrated model — shoot branching is controlled by the balance of auxin (inhibitory, via SLs), strigolactones (directly inhibitory), and cytokinins (promotive), with additional input from sugars (as a systemic signal of carbon availability). Ethylene (A), gibberellin (B), and ABA (C) do not play the primary roles described.

questions.question: Wood grain in a tree trunk has a characteristic pattern because the vascular cambium produces more secondary xylem on one side of the trunk. This asymmetric growth is called:
options: Reaction wood — in conifers, compression wood forms on the lower (compression) side of leaning stems with extra lignin, while in angiosperms, tension wood forms on the upper (tension) side with gelatinous fibers rich in cellulose; both types result from differential cambial activity stimulated by gravity perception and auxin redistribution
Heartwood formation creating distinct coloration
Periderm regeneration after bark injury
Apoplastic loading of sugars into the phloem
questions.explanation: Reaction wood is a remarkable adaptive response in woody plants: (1) Definition — reaction wood is wood with altered anatomy and composition that forms in response to mechanical stress, particularly gravity. It develops on one side of leaning or horizontally oriented stems and branches, helping the plant return to vertical growth or support the weight of horizontal branches. (2) Compression wood (conifers) — forms on the LOWER side of leaning conifer stems (the compression side). Characteristics: tracheids are shorter and rounder in cross-section, have thicker secondary walls with more lignin (especially in the S2 layer), contain more galactans and less cellulose, appear darker in cross-section. Compression wood pushes the stem upward by expanding as it matures. (3) Tension wood (angiosperms) — forms on the UPPER side of leaning angiosperm stems (the tension side). Characteristics: fibers contain a special 'gelatinous layer' (G-layer) in their secondary walls, composed almost entirely of highly crystalline cellulose with very little lignin. The G-layer contracts as it matures (like a muscle), pulling the stem upward. Tension wood often appears lighter and has a silky/woolly texture when cut. (4) Hormonal control — auxin redistribution plays a key role. In horizontally placed stems, auxin accumulates on the lower side (similar to gravitropism in elongating organs). In conifers, high auxin on the lower side stimulates compression wood formation. In angiosperms, the mechanism is different — tension wood forms on the upper side where auxin concentration may be lower, and ethylene is also involved. (5) Practical significance — reaction wood is problematic in timber because it warps during drying and has different mechanical properties. Heartwood (B), periderm (C), and phloem loading (D) are unrelated processes.

questions.question: In the developing Arabidopsis root epidermis, root hair cell fate is determined by positional signaling. Which cells develop into trichoblasts (root hair cells)?
options: All epidermal cells equally produce root hairs
Random cells selected by stochastic gene expression

Epidermal cells overlying the junction between two cortical cells (H position) — the TTG1/GL3/EGL3/WER complex activates GL2 in non-hair (N) cells to suppress root hair fate, while CPC moves from N cells to H cells where it inhibits WER, allowing root hair development in a position-dependent pattern
Only cells at the root tip that contact the soil surface directly
questions.explanation: Root hair patterning in Arabidopsis is one of the best-understood examples of cell fate determination by positional information in plants: (1) Position-dependent pattern — Arabidopsis root epidermis has two cell types: trichoblasts (root hair cells, H cells) and atrichoblasts (non-hair cells, N cells). H cells develop exclusively over the anticlinal walls between two underlying cortical cells (the H position), while N cells develop over single cortical cells (the N position). (2) Molecular mechanism in N cells — in N-position cells, the transcription factor WEREWOLF (WER, a MYB protein) forms a complex with TRANSPARENT TESTA GLABRA1 (TTG1, a WD40 protein) and GL3/EGL3 (bHLH proteins). This complex activates GLABRA2 (GL2), a homeodomain-leucine zipper transcription factor that suppresses root hair differentiation. Thus, N cells become non-hair cells. (3) Lateral inhibition — the WER-TTG1-GL3/EGL3 complex also activates CAPRICE (CPC) and TRY (TRIPTYCHON), small MYB-like proteins that LACK a transcriptional activation domain. CPC protein moves from N cells to H cells through plasmodesmata. In H cells, CPC competes with WER for binding to the TTG1-GL3/EGL3 complex, forming a CPC-TTG1-GL3/EGL3 complex that CANNOT activate GL2. Without GL2, H cells proceed to root hair fate. (4) Positional signal — the signal that distinguishes H and N positions originates from cortical cells. The receptor-like kinase SCRAMBLED (SCM) on epidermal cells perceives an unknown ligand from cortical cells and modulates WER expression in a position-dependent manner. (5) Similarity to trichome patterning — remarkably, the same gene regulatory network (with homologous components) controls trichome patterning in leaves, but in reverse: GL1/WER-TTG1-GL3/EGL3 promotes trichome fate, and CPC/TRY provides lateral inhibition. All epidermal cells (A), random selection (B), and tip cells only (D) are incorrect.

questions.question: A researcher cross-sections stems at different developmental stages and measures the ratio of secondary xylem to secondary phloem produced by the vascular cambium. At all stages examined, the xylem:phloem ratio is approximately 4:1 to 6:1. Which of the following best explains this consistent asymmetry?
options: The cambium only divides toward the xylem side
All cambial derivatives become xylem; phloem arises from a different source
Secondary phloem is continuously crushed by expanding secondary xylem so it appears thinner

Fusiform initials in the cambium undergo more periclinal divisions toward the xylem side than the phloem side, AND older secondary phloem is progressively crushed and compressed by the expanding xylem — both differential production rates and mechanical compression contribute to the higher xylem:phloem ratio observed in cross-sections
questions.explanation: The asymmetric production of secondary xylem and phloem is a fundamental feature of secondary growth: (1) Differential division — the vascular cambium (specifically, the fusiform initials that produce axial elements) undergoes periclinal divisions (parallel to the surface) to produce derivatives on both sides. However, more divisions occur toward the xylem side than the phloem side. This is an inherent asymmetry in cambial activity, regulated by hormonal gradients (particularly auxin, which is highest in the cambial zone and may preferentially stimulate xylem-side divisions) and polar auxin transport. (2) Mechanical compression — as new secondary xylem accumulates internally (rigid, lignified tissue), it pushes the cambium outward. The secondary phloem, located between the cambium and the bark, is progressively compressed by this expansion. Older phloem cells are crushed, their walls collapsed, and they become non-functional. Only the most recently produced phloem (usually the current year's growth) remains functional. (3) Both factors contribute — the observed 4:1 to 6:1 ratio results from both (a) more xylem-side cell production and (b) compression of existing phloem. If you could account for crushed phloem, the true production ratio might be closer to 3:1 or 4:1. (4) Functional logic — this asymmetry makes biological sense. Xylem must accumulate because: (a) old xylem remains functional for water transport for years (sapwood), and (b) the accumulated wood provides mechanical support. Phloem, conversely, needs only the most recent cells to function. The cambium does divide toward both sides (A is wrong), phloem does arise from the cambium (B is wrong), and while crushing occurs (C), it is not the sole explanation (D provides the complete picture).

questions.question: Stomatal development in the Arabidopsis leaf epidermis follows a strict pattern where mature stomata are always separated by at least one non-stomatal (pavement) cell. The gene responsible for enforcing this 'one-cell spacing rule' is:
options: SPEECHLESS (SPCH), which initiates the stomatal lineage
FAMA, which promotes the final symmetric division producing guard cells

TOO MANY MOUTHS (TMM), a leucine-rich repeat receptor-like protein that restricts stomatal precursor divisions to enforce the spacing pattern — tmm mutants produce stomatal clusters where guard cells are in direct contact, violating the one-cell spacing rule
MUTE, which promotes the transition from meristemoid to guard mother cell
questions.explanation: Stomatal patterning is a model system for understanding cell-cell signaling during plant development: (1) The one-cell spacing rule — in wild-type Arabidopsis, mature stomata are always separated by at least one pavement cell. This spacing ensures that each stoma can function independently (adjacent stomata would interfere with each other's ability to open and close). (2) Stomatal development pathway — the basic lineage is: protodermal cell → meristemoid mother cell (MMC) → meristemoid → guard mother cell (GMC) → two guard cells. Key transcription factors control each transition: SPEECHLESS (SPCH, bHLH) initiates entry into the stomatal lineage; MUTE (bHLH) promotes the meristemoid-to-GMC transition; FAMA (bHLH) promotes the final symmetric GMC division and guard cell differentiation. (3) TMM function — TOO MANY MOUTHS (TMM) is a leucine-rich repeat receptor-like protein (LRR-RLP) that lacks an intracellular kinase domain. TMM functions at the cell surface as part of a receptor complex (with ERECTA family receptor kinases: ER, ERL1, ERL2) that perceives peptide signals (EPF/EPFL family) from existing stomatal precursors. This signaling inhibits adjacent cells from entering the stomatal lineage. (4) tmm mutant phenotype — in tmm loss-of-function mutants, the spacing mechanism fails, resulting in clusters of stomata in direct contact. This demonstrates that TMM is essential for enforcing the spacing rule through lateral inhibition. (5) EPF peptides — EPIDERMAL PATTERNING FACTOR 1 (EPF1) and EPF2 are secreted peptides from stomatal lineage cells that signal through TMM-ER receptor complexes to inhibit stomatal fate in neighboring cells. STOMAGEN (EPFL9), conversely, is a positive regulator secreted from mesophyll cells. SPCH (A) and MUTE (D) control stomatal lineage entry/transition, while FAMA (B) controls guard cell differentiation, but none enforce spacing.

questions.question: Heartwood differs from sapwood in that heartwood:
options: Is the region of active water conduction in the xylem
Contains living parenchyma cells that store starch
Is composed of the most recently produced secondary xylem

Consists of older secondary xylem in which the vessels/tracheids are no longer functional, the parenchyma cells have died, and the wood is often impregnated with phenolic compounds, oils, gums, and resins that give it a darker color and increased resistance to decay — heartwood provides structural support but does not conduct water
questions.explanation: The heartwood-sapwood distinction is fundamental to understanding tree trunk anatomy: (1) Sapwood (alburnum) — the outer region of wood (secondary xylem) that is physiologically active. It contains: (a) functional vessels and tracheids that conduct water, (b) living ray and axial parenchyma cells that store starch, lipids, and minerals, and (c) living contact cells that are involved in loading/unloading the transpiration stream. Sapwood is typically lighter in color. (2) Heartwood (duramen) — the inner region of wood that is no longer physiologically active. As the tree grows, the oldest sapwood is progressively converted to heartwood through a process called 'heartwood formation' or 'duraminization': (a) Parenchyma cells die after depositing various secondary metabolites into the surrounding cell walls and vessel lumens. (b) Tyloses (balloon-like outgrowths of parenchyma cells through pit pairs) may block vessel lumens. (c) Phenolic compounds (tannins, flavonoids), oils, gums, and resins are deposited, darkening the wood and making it more resistant to fungal decay and insect attack. (3) Structural function — heartwood still provides critical mechanical support (it is the structural core of the tree trunk), even though it no longer transports water. A tree can survive with a hollow heartwood core (as in many ancient trees) because water transport occurs only in the sapwood. (4) Variable width — sapwood width varies by species: some species (like teak) have narrow sapwood, while others (like maple) have wide sapwood. The heartwood-sapwood boundary is often visible as a color change in cross-sections. Active water conduction (A), living parenchyma (B), and recent xylem (C) all describe sapwood, not heartwood.

questions.question: A researcher wants to test whether the SHR (SHORT-ROOT) transcription factor moves from the stele to the endodermis to specify endodermal cell identity. The most definitive experiment would be to:
options: Measure SHR mRNA levels in whole root extracts
Observe root morphology in shr mutants without molecular analysis

Express SHR-GFP fusion protein from the SHR native promoter (stele-specific) and use confocal microscopy to track GFP fluorescence — if SHR protein moves, GFP signal should be detected in both the stele (where SHR mRNA is transcribed) and the endodermis (where SHR protein has moved); combining this with SHR promoter::GFP (transcriptional reporter) showing GFP only in the stele confirms that the protein moves post-translationally
Apply exogenous SHR protein to the root surface
questions.explanation: The movement of SHR from stele to endodermis is a landmark discovery in plant developmental biology, demonstrated by Nakajima et al. (2001): (1) The key distinction — to prove protein movement, you must distinguish between where a gene is transcribed (mRNA location) and where the protein accumulates. This requires two types of reporters: (a) Transcriptional reporter (SHR promoter::GFP): GFP is expressed from the SHR promoter but is not fused to SHR protein. GFP produced this way stays in the cells where the promoter is active. This shows WHERE SHR IS TRANSCRIBED. (b) Translational reporter (SHR promoter::SHR-GFP fusion): GFP is fused to the SHR protein itself. This fusion protein goes wherever SHR protein goes, including to cells where SHR moves but is not transcribed. (2) The experimental result — transcriptional reporter: GFP only in stele cells (confirming SHR transcription is stele-specific). Translational reporter: GFP-SHR detected in both stele AND endodermis (demonstrating that SHR protein moves from stele to endodermis). This comparison conclusively proves SHR protein moves. (3) Movement mechanism — SHR moves through plasmodesmata. Once in the endodermis, SHR activates SCARECROW (SCR), and SHR-SCR together activate downstream targets that specify endodermal identity (including Casparian strip formation). (4) Restriction mechanism — SHR protein is restricted to moving only one cell layer (to the endodermis) by SCR-mediated sequestration: SCR physically binds SHR and sequesters it in the endodermal nucleus, preventing further outward movement. (5) Why other options fail — whole-root mRNA (A) doesn't reveal protein location; morphology alone (B) doesn't prove movement mechanism; exogenous protein application (D) is not feasible and doesn't demonstrate endogenous movement.

questions.question: The cell plate that forms during cytokinesis in plant cells is built by the fusion of vesicles derived from which organelle?
options: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
Vacuole membrane (tonoplast)

The Golgi apparatus (trans-Golgi network) — Golgi-derived vesicles containing cell wall precursors (pectins, hemicelluloses, callose) are transported along the phragmoplast microtubules to the division plane, where they fuse to form the cell plate that matures into the new cell wall and middle lamella separating daughter cells
Plasma membrane invagination from the cell periphery
questions.explanation: Cell plate formation during plant cytokinesis is fundamentally different from animal cell division: (1) No cleavage furrow — unlike animal cells, which divide by cleavage furrow (actin-myosin ring constriction from outside in), plant cells divide by building a new wall from inside out. This is because the rigid cell wall prevents constriction. (2) Phragmoplast — the phragmoplast is a specialized structure composed of antiparallel microtubule arrays, actin filaments, and associated proteins that forms between the two daughter nuclei during late telophase. It guides vesicle traffic to the division plane. (3) Golgi-derived vesicles — the trans-Golgi network produces vesicles loaded with cell wall matrix materials: pectins (especially homogalacturonan, which becomes the middle lamella), hemicelluloses (xyloglucans, xylans), and callose (beta-1,3-glucan, important for early cell plate structure). These vesicles are transported along phragmoplast microtubules by kinesin motor proteins to the cell plate assembly site. (4) Cell plate maturation — (a) Early stage: vesicles fuse to form a tubular-vesicular network at the center of the division plane. (b) Intermediate stage: the network transitions to a tubular network, then a fenestrated sheet. Callose is deposited for structural support. (c) Late stage: the sheet becomes a continuous, smooth disk that fuses with the parental cell wall at the cell periphery. Callose is replaced by cellulose. The new wall matures into a complete cell wall with middle lamella. (5) Plasmodesmata formation — primary plasmodesmata form during cell plate construction when ER tubules become trapped in the forming plate, creating membrane-lined channels. Smooth ER (A), tonoplast (B), and plasma membrane invagination (D) do not build the cell plate.

questions.question: Plasmodesmata allow symplastic communication between adjacent plant cells. Which structural component forms the central core of a plasmodesma, regulating its molecular size exclusion limit?
options: An actin filament bundle spanning the channel
A cellulose microfibril bridging the two cell walls
A simple aqueous pore with no internal structure

The desmotubule — a thin tube of appressed endoplasmic reticulum membrane that runs through the center of the plasmodesma, creating an annular space (the cytoplasmic sleeve) between the desmotubule and the plasma membrane lining the channel; calreticulin and other ER-associated proteins on the desmotubule surface help regulate the size exclusion limit
questions.explanation: Plasmodesmata are sophisticated intercellular channels unique to plants: (1) Basic structure — a plasmodesma is a membrane-lined channel (20-50 nm diameter) that traverses the cell wall between adjacent cells. The plasma membrane of one cell is continuous with that of the neighboring cell through the plasmodesma, creating a shared membrane surface. (2) Desmotubule — the central core of each plasmodesma is the desmotubule, a thin cylindrical tube formed by appressed (tightly compressed) endoplasmic reticulum membranes. The ER of one cell is continuous with the ER of the adjacent cell through the desmotubule, creating both cytoplasmic and endomembrane continuity between cells. (3) Cytoplasmic sleeve — the space between the outer surface of the desmotubule and the inner surface of the plasma membrane lining the channel is called the cytoplasmic sleeve. This annular space (about 3-4 nm in simple plasmodesmata) is the primary pathway for molecular transport. (4) Size exclusion limit (SEL) — the cytoplasmic sleeve restricts passage of molecules above a certain size. The default SEL is typically 800-1000 daltons (allowing passage of ions, sugars, amino acids, small signaling molecules). However, the SEL can be dynamically regulated: callose deposition at the neck regions narrows the aperture (decreasing SEL), while beta-1,3-glucanase activity removes callose (increasing SEL). Some proteins (e.g., transcription factors like SHR, KN1) and viruses can actively dilate plasmodesmata to increase the SEL for their own trafficking. (5) Proteins associated with the desmotubule — calreticulin, actin, and myosin have been localized to plasmodesmata and may participate in regulating transport. Actin filaments (A) are associated but do not form the core; cellulose (B) and simple pores (C) do not describe the structure correctly.

questions.question: The shoot apical meristem (SAM) is organized into distinct zones. Which zone gives rise to lateral organ primordia such as leaves?
options: The central zone (CZ), which contains slowly dividing stem cells
The organizing center (OC), which maintains stem cell identity
The rib meristem, which produces internal stem tissues

The peripheral zone (PZ) — cells displaced laterally from the central zone into the peripheral zone divide more rapidly and are recruited into leaf, flower, and axillary bud primordia; organ initiation in the PZ is marked by local auxin accumulation maxima created by PIN1-mediated polar auxin transport
questions.explanation: The functional zonation of the SAM is critical for understanding how plants continuously produce new organs: (1) Central zone (CZ) — contains the stem cell population. Cells here divide relatively slowly and serve as the ultimate source of all cells in the shoot. The CZ is maintained by the WUS-CLV feedback loop: WUS from the organizing center maintains stem cells, which produce CLV3 to restrict WUS expression. (2) Organizing center (OC) — a small group of cells beneath the CZ that express WUS. The OC maintains CZ stem cell identity but does not directly produce organs. (3) Peripheral zone (PZ) — cells displaced from the CZ to the PZ transition to a more rapid cell division rate and become competent for organ formation. Lateral organ primordia (leaves, flowers, axillary meristems) initiate in the PZ. (4) Auxin-mediated organ initiation — organ primordia form at sites of auxin accumulation maxima in the PZ. PIN1 (an auxin efflux carrier) directs auxin toward convergence points on the meristem surface, creating local auxin peaks. These peaks trigger the expression of organ identity genes and the outgrowth of primordia. The pattern of auxin maxima (and thus organ positioning) is determined by the feedback between existing primordia (which deplete local auxin, creating 'inhibitory fields') and PIN1-directed auxin transport. This generates the regular phyllotactic patterns (spiral, distichous, whorled) observed in different species. (5) Rib meristem — located below the CZ, produces the internal tissues of the stem (pith). The CZ (A) maintains stem cells but does not directly form organs; the OC (B) signals to maintain stem cells; the rib meristem (C) produces stem internal tissues.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the difference between primary and secondary cell walls in plant cells?
options: Primary walls are produced after cell expansion ceases, while secondary walls form during elongation

Secondary walls are deposited inside the primary wall after the cell has stopped growing — they are thicker, contain more cellulose with higher crystallinity, are often impregnated with lignin, and are laid down in distinct layers (S1, S2, S3) with different microfibril orientations that confer exceptional mechanical strength
Primary walls contain lignin while secondary walls consist only of cellulose
Primary and secondary walls are chemically identical but differ only in thickness
questions.explanation: The distinction between primary and secondary cell walls is fundamental to plant cell biology: (1) Primary cell wall — deposited during cell growth. It must be extensible to allow cell expansion driven by turgor pressure. Composition: relatively thin (0.1-1 micrometer), contains cellulose microfibrils (15-30% dry weight) embedded in a matrix of hemicelluloses (xyloglucans in eudicots, mixed-linkage glucans in grasses), pectins (homogalacturonan, rhamnogalacturonan I/II), and structural glycoproteins (extensins, arabinogalactan proteins). The matrix polymers create a gel-like, hydrated structure that can be loosened by expansin proteins and other wall-modifying enzymes to allow growth. (2) Secondary cell wall — deposited INSIDE (between the plasma membrane and the primary wall) after cell expansion has ceased. Much thicker (1-10 micrometers or more). Higher cellulose content (40-60%) with more crystalline microfibrils, less matrix material, and often extensive lignification (10-25% lignin). (3) S1-S2-S3 layering — secondary walls are deposited in three distinct layers: S1 (outermost, thin, microfibrils nearly transverse), S2 (thickest layer, 75-85% of wall thickness, microfibrils at a steep angle close to the cell axis), S3 (innermost, thin, microfibrils nearly transverse). The alternating microfibril angles between layers create a plywood-like structure with exceptional strength. (4) Lignification — lignin is a complex phenolic polymer deposited primarily in secondary walls (and middle lamella). It provides compressive strength, waterproofing, and resistance to microbial degradation. Lignification is characteristic of xylem elements and sclerenchyma. (5) Irreversibility — once a secondary wall is deposited and lignified, the cell typically undergoes programmed cell death (as in tracheids, vessel elements, and fibers). Option A reverses the order, C incorrectly assigns lignin to primary walls, and D ignores chemical differences.

questions.question: A student examines leaf cross-sections from sun and shade environments of the same plant species. Sun leaves show thicker mesophyll with more layers of palisade parenchyma, while shade leaves have thinner mesophyll with fewer palisade layers but more chloroplasts per cell. This variation represents:
options: A genetic mutation that arose in the shade population
Convergent evolution between two unrelated species
Random variation with no functional significance

Developmental plasticity (phenotypic plasticity) — the same genotype produces different leaf anatomy in response to light environment during development; sun leaves maximize photosynthetic capacity per unit area through thick palisade tissue, while shade leaves maximize light capture efficiency with fewer cell layers and more chloroplasts per cell, optimizing each leaf for its specific light regime
questions.explanation: Developmental plasticity in leaf anatomy is a classic example of how plants respond to environmental variation: (1) Phenotypic plasticity defined — the ability of a single genotype to produce different phenotypes in response to different environmental conditions. Since plants cannot move, developmental plasticity is a critical adaptive strategy. Leaf anatomy plasticity in response to light is one of the best-documented examples. (2) Sun leaf characteristics — high light intensity during leaf development induces: thicker leaves overall, more layers of palisade mesophyll (the columnar cells below the upper epidermis that are the primary photosynthetic cells), thicker palisade cells, higher density of stomata, more rubisco and photosynthetic electron transport components per area, higher maximum photosynthetic rate. (3) Shade leaf characteristics — low light intensity during development produces: thinner leaves, fewer palisade layers (often just one), larger and thinner mesophyll cells with more intercellular air spaces, more chloroplasts per cell with higher chlorophyll b:a ratio (absorbs more blue and red light), larger light-harvesting antenna complexes, lower light compensation point (can achieve net positive photosynthesis at lower light levels). (4) Adaptive significance — sun leaves are optimized for maximum photosynthetic rate under high light (investment in rubisco and electron transport capacity). Shade leaves are optimized for efficient light capture under limiting light (investment in light-harvesting pigments and antenna size). (5) Developmental mechanism — the light environment during leaf development (specifically the red:far-red ratio, blue light intensity, and total photosynthetically active radiation) signals through photoreceptors (phytochrome, cryptochrome) to regulate cell division patterns and chloroplast biogenesis in developing leaf primordia. This is not genetic mutation (A), convergent evolution (B), or random variation (C).

questions.question: The middle lamella, the outermost layer shared between adjacent plant cells, is composed primarily of:
options: Cellulose microfibrils
Lignin polymers
Suberin and cutin waxes

Pectins, particularly calcium-cross-linked homogalacturonan — calcium ions bridge the negatively charged carboxyl groups of galacturonic acid residues on adjacent pectin chains (the 'egg-box' model), creating a gel-like adhesive layer that cements neighboring cells together
questions.explanation: The middle lamella plays a critical role in cell-cell adhesion in plant tissues: (1) Composition — the middle lamella is composed predominantly of pectins, especially homogalacturonan (HG), a linear polymer of alpha-1,4-linked galacturonic acid residues. Galacturonic acid carries carboxyl groups (-COOH) that can be ionized to -COO- at physiological pH, providing negative charges. (2) Calcium cross-linking — divalent calcium ions (Ca2+) bridge pairs of negatively charged carboxyl groups on adjacent HG chains, creating ionic cross-links. This cross-linking is described by the 'egg-box' model: two antiparallel HG chains form a structure resembling an egg carton, with Ca2+ ions sitting in the 'hollows' between them. The degree of calcium cross-linking determines the rigidity of the pectin gel. (3) Methyl-esterification — newly secreted HG is highly methyl-esterified (the carboxyl groups are blocked by methyl groups). Pectin methylesterases (PMEs) in the cell wall remove methyl groups, exposing carboxyl groups for calcium cross-linking. The degree and pattern of de-methyl-esterification thus controls pectin gel strength and cell-cell adhesion. (4) Cell separation — when cells need to separate (e.g., during fruit ripening, abscission, lateral root emergence), enzymes such as polygalacturonase and pectate lyase degrade the pectin in the middle lamella, dissolving the adhesive layer. This is why ripe fruits soften — pectin degradation reduces cell-cell adhesion. (5) Distinction from cell wall layers — the middle lamella is distinct from the primary wall (which contains cellulose, hemicelluloses, and pectins) and secondary wall (cellulose, hemicelluloses, lignin). Cellulose (A) is the main structural polysaccharide of cell walls but not the middle lamella. Lignin (B) and suberin/cutin (C) are found in specialized wall types.

questions.question: To test whether auxin polar transport establishes the phyllotactic pattern at the shoot apical meristem, a researcher should:
options: Remove all leaves from the plant and observe regrowth

Apply a uniform concentration of auxin to the entire meristem surface and observe whether organ initiation sites still form a regular pattern — if polar transport creates local auxin maxima that determine organ positions, flooding the meristem with uniform auxin should disrupt the normal phyllotactic pattern
Measure stem height over time
Count the final number of leaves at plant maturity
questions.explanation: Phyllotaxis — the arrangement of leaves and other lateral organs around the stem — is one of the most beautiful examples of self-organization in biology, and auxin plays a central role: (1) Auxin convergence model — Reinhardt et al. (2003) showed that PIN1-mediated polar auxin transport creates local auxin maxima at the shoot apical meristem surface. Existing primordia act as auxin sinks (they drain auxin from their surroundings), creating auxin depletion zones around themselves. New primordia can only form at positions far enough from existing ones where auxin can accumulate — typically at the next available maximum in the auxin distribution. This generates the regular phyllotactic patterns (e.g., spiral with Fibonacci angles). (2) Experimental prediction — if phyllotaxis depends on PIN1-created auxin maxima, then disrupting the spatial pattern of auxin should disrupt organ positioning. Applying uniform exogenous auxin (e.g., by placing a ring of auxin-soaked lanolin around the meristem) should obliterate the local concentration differences that specify organ positions. Indeed, Reinhardt et al. showed that: (a) Applying auxin transport inhibitors (NPA) to the meristem blocked all organ initiation (no local maxima could form). (b) Applying micro-droplets of auxin to NPA-treated meristems could induce organ formation at the application site (restoring local maxima artificially). (c) Uniform auxin application disrupted the regular pattern. (3) PIN1 dynamics — PIN1 proteins are dynamically polarized in epidermal cells of the meristem, pointing toward convergence points where auxin accumulates. This positive feedback (more auxin attracts more PIN1 polarity, which brings more auxin) creates sharp maxima surrounded by depletion zones. (4) Mathematical modeling — Jonsson et al. (2006) and Smith et al. (2006) showed that models of auxin transport with PIN1 feedback can recapitulate diverse phyllotactic patterns. Removing leaves (A), measuring height (C), and counting final leaves (D) do not directly test the role of polar transport in patterning.

questions.question: Lenticels are structures found in the periderm of woody stems. Their primary function is:
options: Photosynthesis in the bark layer
Absorption of rainwater through the bark surface
Storage of excess starch and lipids

Gas exchange between the internal tissues and the atmosphere — lenticels are regions of loosely arranged cells (complementary cells) in the cork, with large intercellular spaces that allow O2 and CO2 to diffuse through the otherwise gas-impermeable suberized cork layer, enabling aerobic respiration in living cells beneath the bark
questions.explanation: Lenticels are essential for gas exchange in stems with secondary growth: (1) The problem — as secondary growth proceeds, the epidermis (with its stomata) is replaced by the periderm. Cork cells in the periderm are dead, suberized, and essentially gas-impermeable. Without a mechanism for gas exchange, the living cells beneath the bark (phloem parenchyma, cambium, young xylem parenchyma) would be unable to obtain O2 for aerobic respiration or release CO2. (2) Lenticel structure — lenticels form at locations where the cork cambium (phellogen) produces loosely arranged, unsuberized or partially suberized cells called complementary cells (filling tissue) instead of regular compact cork. These cells have large intercellular spaces that create a porous pathway through the periderm. (3) Visual appearance — lenticels appear as raised bumps, dots, or elongated marks on the bark surface of young twigs and branches. They are visible to the naked eye on many species (birch, cherry, apple). In some species, lenticels are the dominant visual feature of young bark. (4) Development — lenticels often form beneath former stomata positions in the original epidermis. As secondary growth begins and the periderm replaces the epidermis, the cork cambium underlying stomata produces complementary cells rather than compact cork, maintaining a gas exchange pathway at these positions. (5) Environmental adaptations — in flood-adapted species, hypertrophied lenticels (enlarged lenticels with very loose tissue) form on submerged portions of the stem, facilitating O2 entry to waterlogged roots through aerenchyma pathways. Lenticels do not perform photosynthesis (A), absorb water (B), or store reserves (C).

questions.question: In root anatomy, the pericycle is a critical tissue layer. Which of the following best describes its location and developmental potential?
options: It is the outermost layer of the cortex, external to the endodermis
It is a single layer of dead cells forming the outer boundary of the vascular cylinder
It is found only in stems, not roots

It is the outermost layer of the vascular cylinder (stele), located just inside the endodermis — pericycle cells retain meristematic competence and give rise to lateral roots, and in eudicots the pericycle contributes to the vascular cambium and the first cork cambium during secondary growth
questions.explanation: The pericycle is a uniquely versatile tissue with remarkable developmental potential: (1) Location — the pericycle is a cylinder of parenchyma cells that forms the outermost layer of the stele (vascular cylinder), positioned immediately internal to the endodermis. In cross-section, it appears as one to several layers of cells between the endodermis and the primary vascular tissues (xylem and phloem). (2) Meristematic competence — pericycle cells, although they appear differentiated, retain the ability to re-enter the cell cycle and divide. This is relatively unusual for cells outside meristems and gives the pericycle its remarkable versatility. (3) Lateral root formation — the most prominent function of pericycle cells is initiating lateral roots. Founder cells in the pericycle (typically opposite protoxylem poles) are specified by auxin accumulation, re-enter mitosis, and produce lateral root primordia that grow through the cortex and epidermis (endogenous origin). (4) Contribution to secondary growth — in eudicots that undergo secondary growth in roots: (a) Pericycle cells opposite the xylem poles contribute to the vascular cambium. The complete cambium ring forms from fascicular cambium between xylem and phloem strands plus interfascicular cambium from pericycle cells. (b) The first cork cambium (phellogen) in roots typically arises from pericycle cells, initiating periderm formation. (5) Not external (A) — the pericycle is inside the endodermis, not outside it. Not dead (B) — pericycle cells are living, metabolically active cells. Found in roots (C is wrong) — the pericycle is a root tissue; stems have equivalent tissues but the term pericycle is primarily applied to roots.

questions.question: Expansins are a family of proteins critical for plant growth. They promote cell wall extension by:
options: Synthesizing new cellulose microfibrils to replace broken ones
Cross-linking pectin molecules to stiffen the wall
Degrading lignin in the secondary cell wall

Disrupting non-covalent bonds (hydrogen bonds) between cellulose microfibrils and hemicellulose (xyloglucan) tethers in the primary cell wall — this loosening allows turgor-driven cell expansion without enzymatic cleavage of wall polymers; expansin activity is pH-dependent, with maximum activity at acidic pH, consistent with the acid growth theory
questions.explanation: Expansins are central to the mechanism of plant cell expansion and directly support the acid growth theory: (1) The acid growth theory — auxin-induced cell elongation proceeds via the following pathway: auxin activates plasma membrane H+-ATPases (proton pumps) that acidify the cell wall space (from pH ~7 to pH ~4.5-5). The acidified wall activates expansins, which loosen the wall, allowing turgor-driven expansion. (2) Expansin mechanism — expansins are small proteins (25-27 kDa) that do NOT have enzymatic (hydrolytic) activity. Instead, they disrupt the non-covalent hydrogen bonds between cellulose microfibrils and the hemicellulose (xyloglucan in eudicots, mixed-linkage glucan and arabinoxylan in grasses) tethers that cross-link them. This relaxation of the cellulose-hemicellulose network allows microfibrils to slide relative to each other when pulled by turgor pressure, resulting in irreversible cell wall extension. (3) pH dependence — expansins have optimal activity at acidic pH (4.5-5.5), consistent with the acid growth theory. When the wall is acidified by proton pumps, expansins become active and loosen the wall. (4) Protein families — there are two main families: alpha-expansins (EXPA, ~26 members in Arabidopsis) involved primarily in developmental growth, and beta-expansins (EXPB, ~6 members) found predominantly in grasses (some are major pollen allergens, e.g., Zea m 1 group 1 grass pollen allergen). (5) Biological roles — expansins are involved in virtually every process requiring cell wall modification: cell elongation, lateral root emergence, fruit ripening, seed germination, leaf development, and abscission. They do not synthesize cellulose (A), cross-link pectins (B), or degrade lignin (C).

questions.question:
Match the following leaf anatomical features with their primary functions:
(P) Palisade mesophyll
(Q) Spongy mesophyll
(R) Bundle sheath extensions
(S) Abaxial epidermis with higher stomatal density

1. Facilitates gas exchange within the leaf through interconnected air spaces; also participates in photosynthesis
2. Contains tightly packed columnar cells oriented perpendicular to the leaf surface for maximum light interception and photosynthesis
3. Columns of parenchyma or sclerenchyma connecting vascular bundles to the epidermis; facilitate water distribution and provide structural support
4. Allows CO2 uptake preferentially from the shaded underside, reducing water loss compared to adaxial stomata exposed to direct sunlight
questions.explanation: Leaf internal anatomy is exquisitely adapted for photosynthesis and gas exchange: (1) Palisade mesophyll (P-2) — one or more layers of elongated, columnar cells packed tightly together, oriented with their long axes perpendicular to the leaf surface (and thus parallel to incoming light). This orientation maximizes light capture: light passes along the length of each cell, through multiple chloroplasts arranged along the cell periphery. Palisade cells contain the majority (70-80%) of leaf chloroplasts and are the primary site of photosynthesis. Located adaxially (upper side) in most leaves. (2) Spongy mesophyll (Q-1) — irregularly shaped cells with abundant intercellular air spaces (up to 50% of spongy mesophyll volume is air). These air spaces form a connected network that facilitates gas diffusion (CO2 from stomata to photosynthetic cells, O2 from cells to stomata). Spongy mesophyll also performs photosynthesis but less efficiently than palisade due to lower chloroplast density and less optimal light exposure. Located abaxially (lower side). (3) Bundle sheath extensions (R-3) — columns of cells (parenchyma or sclerenchyma) extending from vascular bundles to one or both epidermal surfaces. They serve as conduits for water distribution from xylem to the epidermis and provide structural rigidity. In heterobaric leaves, they also compartmentalize the leaf into separate gas-exchange regions. (4) Abaxial stomatal density (S-4) — in most eudicot leaves, stomata are more numerous on the abaxial (lower) surface (hypostomatic leaves). This positioning reduces water loss because the lower surface receives less direct solar radiation and is cooler, reducing the driving force for transpiration. It also reduces UV damage to guard cells.

questions.question: Girdling (ring-barking) a tree — removing a complete ring of bark down to the wood — kills the tree because it removes:
options: All of the xylem, preventing water transport to the leaves
The heartwood that provides structural support
The root system by severing underground connections

The phloem, preventing translocation of sugars from leaves to roots — without a continuous phloem pathway, photosynthate cannot reach the roots, which starve and die; subsequently the entire tree dies because it cannot absorb water and minerals without functional roots
questions.explanation: Girdling is a classic demonstration of the distinct functions of xylem and phloem: (1) What is removed — when bark is removed in a complete ring, the tissues removed include: the outer bark (dead periderm layers), the cork cambium, the cortex (if any remains), ALL of the phloem (both functional secondary phloem and the vascular cambium). The xylem (wood) is left intact. (2) Immediate effects — water transport continues through the intact xylem (sapwood), so the leaves above the girdle remain hydrated and continue photosynthesis initially. However, the phloem is severed, so sugars produced by photosynthesis cannot be translocated downward past the girdle. (3) Sugar accumulation — sugars accumulate above the girdle, often causing visible swelling of the bark just above the cut. Below the girdle, the phloem is starved of sugars. (4) Root starvation — roots depend entirely on photosynthate translocated from the shoots via phloem (roots are heterotrophic). Without sugar supply, roots gradually exhaust their starch reserves, respiration declines, and root cells die. This process may take weeks to months depending on the tree's reserves. (5) Tree death — once roots die, the tree can no longer absorb water and minerals, leading to wilting and death of the above-ground portions as well. Girdling does NOT remove xylem (A — xylem/wood is intact), heartwood (B — heartwood is deep within), or root connections (C — it is performed on the trunk above ground). This experiment conclusively shows that phloem transport is essential for long-term tree survival.

questions.question: The KNOTTED1 (KN1) gene in maize encodes a homeodomain transcription factor that is normally expressed in the shoot apical meristem but not in lateral organ primordia. Gain-of-function mutations that cause ectopic KN1 expression in leaves result in:
options: Normal leaf development without any visible phenotype
Complete absence of all leaves

Knot-like protuberances (outgrowths) on the leaf surface — ectopic KN1 expression maintains meristematic identity in cells that should differentiate, causing localized regions of leaf tissue to continue dividing and form tumor-like growths; this demonstrates that downregulation of KNOX genes is required for normal leaf initiation and differentiation
Accelerated senescence and early leaf drop
questions.explanation: The KNOTTED1 (KN1) gene provides fundamental insights into the relationship between meristem maintenance and organ differentiation: (1) Normal KN1 expression — KN1 is a class I KNOX (KNOTTED-LIKE HOMEOBOX) gene expressed in the SAM. KN1 and related KNOX genes (STM/SHOOT MERISTEMLESS in Arabidopsis) are required to maintain meristematic identity. They promote cell division and inhibit differentiation. (2) Leaf initiation requires KNOX downregulation — when a leaf primordium initiates in the peripheral zone, KN1/KNOX gene expression is rapidly downregulated in the founder cells. This downregulation is mediated by transcription factors like ARP (ASYMMETRIC LEAVES1/ROUGH SHEATH2/PHANTASTICA) family members. Without KNOX repression, cells would maintain meristematic identity and not differentiate into leaf tissue. (3) Gain-of-function phenotype — the original kn1-O (Knotted1-Original) dominant mutation causes ectopic KN1 expression in developing leaves. Cells expressing KN1 maintain meristematic character: they continue dividing in regions where surrounding cells have differentiated. This creates knot-like outgrowths (protuberances) on the leaf blade surface — localized masses of dividing, undifferentiated cells surrounded by normal differentiated leaf tissue. (4) Mobile protein — KN1 protein can move between cells through plasmodesmata, which was one of the first demonstrations of non-cell-autonomous protein trafficking in plants. KN1 actively increases its own molecular trafficking by increasing the plasmodesmatal size exclusion limit. (5) Evolutionary conservation — KNOX-ARP module is conserved across land plants: KNOX genes maintain meristematic identity in the SAM, and ARP genes (which repress KNOX) are required for leaf differentiation. Normal development (A), absent leaves (B), and senescence (D) are not the observed phenotype of ectopic KN1.

questions.question: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of monocot root anatomy compared to eudicot root anatomy?
options: Monocots have a single taproot with few lateral branches
Monocots lack an endodermis in their roots
Monocots always have secondary growth from a vascular cambium in their roots

Monocot roots typically have a large central pith surrounded by a ring of vascular bundles, with xylem and phloem strands alternating in a polyarch arrangement — they also generally lack secondary growth, so the primary anatomy persists throughout the root's life
questions.explanation: Monocot and eudicot roots differ in several important anatomical features: (1) Vascular cylinder arrangement — in monocot roots, the stele is typically large and contains numerous xylem and phloem strands arranged alternately in a ring around a central pith of parenchyma. The arrangement is polyarch (many xylem poles — often 8 or more in large monocot roots like corn). In contrast, eudicot roots are typically diarch to hexarch (2-6 xylem poles) with no pith (xylem occupies the center of the stele). (2) Central pith — the presence of a central pith in the vascular cylinder is characteristic of monocot roots. The pith consists of parenchyma cells that may store starch. In eudicots, the xylem extends to the center of the stele, leaving no pith (except in some species with very thick roots). (3) No secondary growth — monocot roots, like monocot stems, generally do not undergo secondary growth because they lack a vascular cambium. The primary anatomy established by the root apical meristem persists throughout the root's life. Eudicot roots typically develop a vascular cambium from pericycle and procambium cells, producing secondary xylem and phloem. (4) Fibrous root system — monocots typically have a fibrous root system composed of adventitious roots arising from the stem base, not a taproot (A is incorrect — taproot is characteristic of eudicots). (5) Endodermis — both monocots and eudicots have an endodermis with Casparian strips (B is incorrect). In monocots, the endodermis may be particularly prominent with thick-walled State III cells. Monocots do not have secondary growth (C is incorrect).

questions.question: A researcher applies the auxin transport inhibitor TIBA (2,3,5-triiodobenzoic acid) to the shoot apical meristem of tomato plants. After treatment, no new leaf primordia are initiated, and the meristem continues to grow as a naked pin-shaped structure. What conclusion is best supported by this result?
options: Auxin inhibits all cell division in the meristem
TIBA destroyed the meristematic cells by toxicity
Leaf initiation requires gibberellin, not auxin

Polar auxin transport is required for leaf primordium initiation — blocking auxin transport prevents the formation of local auxin maxima in the peripheral zone of the SAM that are necessary to trigger organ formation; the pin-like phenotype demonstrates that the meristem remains functional but cannot specify sites for new organs without auxin-mediated positional signaling
questions.explanation: This experiment is a landmark in understanding phyllotaxis and the role of auxin in organ initiation: (1) Reinhardt et al. (2000) experiment — application of polar auxin transport inhibitors (NPA or TIBA) to tomato shoot apical meristems produced a remarkable result: the meristem continued to grow (adding new cells) but failed to initiate any lateral organs. The result was a pin-shaped or pin-like naked shoot with no leaves. (2) Interpretation — the meristem is not damaged by the inhibitor (it continues to grow). Cell division is not blocked. What is blocked is the spatial patterning of organ initiation sites. Normal organ initiation requires local auxin maxima created by PIN1-mediated polar transport. When transport is inhibited, auxin cannot converge to create the concentration peaks needed to trigger primordium formation. (3) Rescue experiment — crucially, Reinhardt et al. showed that applying micro-beads coated with IAA (auxin) to specific locations on the NPA-treated meristem surface could rescue organ formation at those precise positions. This proved that: (a) local auxin maxima are sufficient to trigger organ initiation, (b) the meristem retains full competence for organ formation, and (c) the defect is specifically in creating local auxin patterns. (4) PIN1 visualization — immunolocalization of PIN1 in the meristem epidermis revealed that PIN1 proteins are polarized toward convergence points where auxin accumulates — these convergence points correspond exactly to incipient organ primordium sites. In pin1 mutants (lacking PIN1 protein), a similar pin-shaped phenotype occurs naturally. (5) Why other options are wrong — auxin does not inhibit all cell division (A — the meristem keeps growing); TIBA is not toxic to meristem cells (B — they continue to divide); gibberellin is not the primary signal for leaf initiation (C — auxin is).

questions.question: Sieve tube elements in angiosperms undergo a remarkable differentiation process. Which of the following changes does NOT occur during sieve tube element maturation?
options: The nucleus degenerates and is lost
The tonoplast (vacuolar membrane) breaks down, creating a continuous lumen
Sieve plates with callose-lined pores form at the end walls

Thick lignified secondary walls are deposited, similar to xylem vessel elements — in reality, sieve tube elements retain thin, unlignified primary walls throughout their functional life, which is essential for their flexibility and for allowing lateral connections with companion cells through plasmodesmata
questions.explanation: Sieve tube element differentiation is one of the most unique developmental processes in plant biology: (1) Nuclear degeneration (A — DOES occur) — the nucleus of the developing sieve tube element undergoes a controlled degeneration. The nuclear envelope breaks down, chromatin condenses and disperses, and the nucleus is eventually lost completely. This is distinct from programmed cell death in xylem, because sieve tube elements remain alive (the plasma membrane stays intact). (2) Tonoplast breakdown (B — DOES occur) — the tonoplast (vacuolar membrane) disintegrates, merging the vacuolar contents with the cytoplasm to create a single continuous lumen. This maximizes the space available for phloem sap flow. Ribosomes are also lost (no rough ER), mitochondria become fewer, and plastids differentiate into S-type (with starch) or P-type (with protein) plastids. (3) Sieve plate formation (C — DOES occur) — end walls between adjacent sieve tube elements develop into sieve plates with enlarged pores (1-15 micrometers diameter) lined with callose. These pores allow mass flow of phloem sap between cells. Callose deposition can be rapidly increased to seal sieve plates after wounding, preventing phloem sap loss (similar to clotting). P-proteins also participate in wound sealing. (4) NO secondary wall deposition (D — DOES NOT occur, correct answer) — sieve tube elements retain only their primary cell wall throughout their functional life. They NEVER deposit secondary walls or lignin. This is essential because: (a) thin walls allow plasmodesmatal connections with companion cells, (b) flexibility is needed for the pressure-flow mechanism, and (c) secondary walls/lignin are associated with cell death (as in xylem), which would be incompatible with the living but enucleate state of functional sieve tubes.

questions.question: Vernalization — the promotion of flowering by extended cold exposure — involves epigenetic silencing of the floral repressor gene FLC (FLOWERING LOCUS C) in Arabidopsis. The molecular mechanism of vernalization involves:
options: Permanent deletion of the FLC gene from the genome during cold exposure
Increasing FLC mRNA stability through poly-A tail extension

Cold-induced histone modifications (particularly H3K27me3 trimethylation) at the FLC chromatin locus, deposited by the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) — this repressive chromatin mark progressively accumulates during cold exposure and is maintained after return to warm temperatures, stably silencing FLC and allowing flowering; the mark is reset in the next generation through germ cell reprogramming
Post-translational ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation of FLC protein only
questions.explanation: Vernalization is an elegant example of environmentally induced epigenetic gene regulation: (1) FLC function — FLC (FLOWERING LOCUS C) is a MADS-box transcription factor that represses flowering by directly binding to and repressing the promoters of key flowering activators including FT (FLORIGEN) and SOC1. High FLC expression prevents flowering; FLC silencing is required for flowering. (2) Cold-induced silencing — during prolonged cold exposure (typically 4-6 weeks at 4 degrees Celsius), a long non-coding RNA called COOLAIR (antisense transcript from FLC) is induced, followed by another lncRNA called COLDAIR (from intron 1 of FLC). These lncRNAs recruit the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2, containing VRN2, CLF/SWN, FIE, MSI1 components) to the FLC chromatin. (3) H3K27me3 deposition — PRC2 trimethylates histone H3 at lysine 27 (H3K27me3), a repressive chromatin mark. During cold, H3K27me3 accumulates progressively at the FLC locus, correlating quantitatively with the duration of cold exposure. VIN3, a PHD-finger protein induced specifically by prolonged cold, is a critical component of the vernalization-specific PRC2 complex. (4) Epigenetic memory — after return to warm temperatures, the H3K27me3 mark at FLC is maintained through cell divisions by a read-write mechanism: existing H3K27me3 marks recruit PRC2, which methylates newly incorporated histones after DNA replication. This creates a stable, mitotically heritable silenced state that persists for the remainder of the plant's life. (5) Resetting — the epigenetic mark is reset during gametogenesis (in the germ cells), restoring high FLC expression in the next generation. This ensures each generation requires its own cold exposure. FLC is not deleted (A), its mRNA is not stabilized (B), and protein degradation alone (D) would not explain the stable memory.

questions.question: Aerenchyma is a specialized tissue found in plants adapted to waterlogged conditions. It is characterized by:
options: Dense sclerenchyma fibers providing mechanical support underwater
Heavily suberized cell walls preventing all gas exchange
Thick-walled cells filled with tannins for pathogen defense

Large, gas-filled intercellular spaces within the cortex — these spaces form either by cell separation (schizogeny) or programmed cell death (lysigeny) and create continuous air channels from shoots to roots, allowing oxygen diffusion from aerial parts to submerged roots for aerobic respiration in the otherwise anoxic waterlogged soil environment
questions.explanation: Aerenchyma is a critical adaptation for survival in wetland and aquatic environments: (1) The problem — waterlogged soils are essentially anaerobic because O2 diffuses 10,000 times more slowly through water than through air. Root cells in flooded soils cannot obtain O2 for aerobic respiration from the surrounding soil environment. (2) Aerenchyma solution — aerenchyma consists of enlarged, gas-filled intercellular spaces (lacunae) that form continuous channels from the shoot system (where O2 is available from the atmosphere or photosynthesis) down through the stems and into the roots. O2 diffuses through these channels to the root tips, maintaining aerobic respiration. CO2 and ethylene diffuse in the reverse direction. (3) Formation mechanisms — (a) Schizogenous aerenchyma: cells separate along their middle lamellae as the organ grows, creating spaces without cell death. Common in stems and petioles. (b) Lysigenous aerenchyma: specific cortical cells undergo ethylene-induced programmed cell death (PCD), and their remnants are resorbed, leaving gas-filled cavities. Common in roots of many species (rice, maize). Ethylene, which accumulates in waterlogged tissues (it cannot escape through water), triggers the PCD process. (4) Species that form aerenchyma — constitutive aerenchyma: always present in obligate wetland plants (Oryza/rice, Juncus, Typha, aquatic plants). Inducible aerenchyma: formed in response to flooding in facultative wetland-adapted species (maize, wheat can form some aerenchyma when flooded). (5) Additional functions — aerenchyma in some wetland plants also facilitates pressurized gas flow (ventilation) in species like Nelumbo (lotus) and Nuphar (water lily), where thermally driven convective flow moves O2 to rhizomes. Dense sclerenchyma (A), suberized walls (B), and tannin-filled cells (C) do not describe aerenchyma.

questions.question: The cuticle covering the aerial epidermis of land plants consists of:
options: A layer of suberin identical to that found in the Casparian strip
Cellulose microfibrils arranged in a lattice on the outer surface

Cutin (a cross-linked polyester of hydroxy fatty acids) embedded in and covered by epicuticular waxes (long-chain alkanes, alcohols, ketones, and esters) — the cuticle provides a hydrophobic barrier that minimizes transpirational water loss from epidermal cells and protects against UV radiation, pathogens, and insect herbivory
A protein-based keratin layer analogous to animal skin
questions.explanation: The cuticle is one of the most important evolutionary innovations enabling plant life on land: (1) Structure — the cuticle has multiple layers from outside to inside: (a) Epicuticular wax — the outermost surface layer, composed of very-long-chain aliphatic compounds (alkanes C29-C33, primary alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, esters, and secondary alcohols). These waxes form crystalline structures (plates, tubes, rods) visible by electron microscopy that create the 'bloom' or glaucous appearance on many plant surfaces. (b) Cuticle proper — cutin (a cross-linked polymer of C16 and C18 hydroxy and epoxy fatty acids esterified together) embedded in waxes (intracuticular waxes). (c) Cuticular layer — the innermost region where cutin and waxes intermingle with cell wall polysaccharides (pectin, cellulose) of the outer epidermal wall. (2) Biosynthesis — cutin monomers and wax precursors are synthesized in epidermal cells (in the ER) and transported across the plasma membrane by ABC transporters and LTPG (lipid transfer protein GPI-anchored) proteins to the cell wall surface, where cutin monomers are polymerized by GDSL lipases/acyltransferases. (3) Water barrier — the cuticle reduces transpirational water loss by >95% compared to a naked cell surface. Without the cuticle, land plants would desiccate rapidly. Cuticular transpiration (water loss through the cuticle despite its hydrophobicity) accounts for 5-10% of total transpiration in most species. (4) Suberin vs. cutin — suberin (A) is chemically related but distinct from cutin: suberin contains more long-chain fatty acids and has an associated aromatic (phenolic) domain, and it occurs in root endodermis and periderm, not the aerial cuticle. Plants do not produce keratin (D — that is an animal protein), and cellulose (B) is not the cuticle material.

questions.question: During secondary growth in a eudicot stem, the vascular cambium is a complete ring of meristematic cells that includes two cell types. These are:
options: Sieve elements and companion cells
Tracheids and vessel elements
Cork cells and phelloderm cells

Fusiform initials and ray initials — fusiform initials are elongated cells that produce the axial system (vessels, tracheids, fibers, sieve tube elements, axial parenchyma) by periclinal divisions, while ray initials are roughly isodiametric cells that produce the radial system (ray parenchyma) extending from the xylem through the cambium to the phloem
questions.explanation: The vascular cambium consists of two types of meristematic cells that generate the two tissue systems of secondary vascular tissue: (1) Fusiform initials — elongated, spindle-shaped cells (100-500 micrometers long, some up to 4 mm in certain species) with tapered ends. They are oriented with their long axis parallel to the stem axis. Through periclinal (tangential) divisions, fusiform initials produce: (a) Inward (toward the pith): secondary xylem derivatives — vessel elements, tracheids, fibers, and axial xylem parenchyma. (b) Outward (toward the bark): secondary phloem derivatives — sieve tube elements, companion cells, fibers, and axial phloem parenchyma. These derivatives constitute the axial system — the vertically oriented cells that function in long-distance transport and support. (2) Ray initials — smaller, roughly isodiametric (equidimensional) cells that produce: (a) Xylem rays (inward): horizontal files of parenchyma cells in the wood. (b) Phloem rays (outward): horizontal files of parenchyma cells in the inner bark. Together these form the radial system (ray system) — horizontally oriented parenchyma cells that function in lateral transport (moving water and sugars radially between xylem and phloem), storage (starch, lipids), and sometimes defense (production of phenolic compounds). (3) Anticlinal divisions — both types of initials also undergo anticlinal (radial) divisions to increase the circumference of the cambium as the stem grows in diameter. (4) Storied vs. nonstoried — in some species, fusiform initials are arranged in neat horizontal tiers (storied cambium), visible as a striped pattern in tangential sections of wood. In others, they are staggered (nonstoried). Sieve elements/companion cells (A) and tracheids/vessels (B) are products of the cambium, not cambial cells themselves. Cork/phelloderm (C) are products of the cork cambium.

questions.question: In Arabidopsis leaf development, the establishment of adaxial (upper) versus abaxial (lower) polarity is controlled by opposing transcription factor families. Which statement correctly describes this regulatory mechanism?
options: Both surfaces express the same genes; polarity arises from differential light exposure only

HD-ZIP III transcription factors specify adaxial identity while KANADI and YABBY family transcription factors specify abaxial identity — a signal from the SAM (likely related to the HD-ZIP III pathway) establishes adaxial polarity in the side of the primordium closest to the meristem, while abaxial determinants are expressed on the outer side, and the boundary between these domains is required for blade outgrowth
Abscisic acid accumulation determines leaf polarity
Polarity is established randomly and fixed by cell wall deposition
questions.explanation: Leaf adaxial-abaxial polarity is a fundamental aspect of leaf development that determines the internal organization of the leaf: (1) The system — in a developing leaf primordium, the side facing the SAM (adaxial) and the side facing away (abaxial) acquire different identities through opposing transcription factor expression: Adaxial: HD-ZIP III family (PHABULOSA/PHB, PHAVOLUTA/PHV, REVOLUTA/REV) and other factors (AS1, AS2). Abaxial: KANADI family (KAN1, KAN2, KAN3), YABBY family (FIL/YABBY1, YAB3), and AUXIN RESPONSE FACTOR3/ETTIN (ARF3/ETT). (2) SAM signal — a signal from the shoot apical meristem induces adaxial identity in the portion of the leaf primordium adjacent to the meristem. This signal is thought to involve the HD-ZIP III pathway. Evidence: surgical separation of a primordium from the SAM causes it to develop with fully abaxial (radialized) identity, demonstrating that the SAM is required for adaxial specification. (3) MicroRNA regulation — miR165/166 are expressed in the abaxial domain and target HD-ZIP III mRNAs for degradation, confining HD-ZIP III proteins to the adaxial domain. ta-siRNA (TAS3) targets ARF3/4 mRNAs, confining these abaxial factors away from the adaxial domain. These small RNA gradients sharpen the boundary. (4) Blade outgrowth — the juxtaposition of adaxial and abaxial domains is REQUIRED for lamina (blade) outgrowth. When either domain is eliminated (e.g., in phb/phv/rev triple mutants → fully abaxialized, or in kan1/kan2 double mutants → partially adaxialized), leaves become radially symmetric and fail to produce a flat blade. This suggests that signaling at the adaxial-abaxial boundary triggers lateral cell proliferation. (5) Internal organization — adaxial domain develops palisade mesophyll and xylem; abaxial domain develops spongy mesophyll and phloem. Light alone (A), ABA (C), and random assignment (D) do not explain leaf polarity.

questions.question: Annual rings in temperate trees are visible because the vascular cambium produces wood with different characteristics during spring and late summer. The earlywood (springwood) differs from the latewood (summerwood) primarily in that earlywood has:
options: More lignin and fewer cells per unit area
Smaller, thicker-walled cells adapted for mechanical strength
No vessels or tracheids, consisting entirely of parenchyma

Larger-diameter, thinner-walled cells (vessels in angiosperms, tracheids in conifers) optimized for water conduction — this reflects rapid spring growth when water demand is high; latewood has smaller, thicker-walled cells providing greater mechanical support, reflecting slower growth during summer when water availability declines
questions.explanation: Annual growth rings are a direct record of seasonal cambial activity: (1) Earlywood (springwood) — produced early in the growing season when conditions favor rapid growth: ample water from snowmelt/spring rains, increasing day length, and rising temperatures. The cambium produces cells optimized for efficient water conduction: large-diameter lumens (wide vessels in angiosperms, wide tracheids in conifers), relatively thin walls, and lower wood density. The large cell size facilitates high-volume water transport needed for spring leaf expansion and rapid shoot growth. (2) Latewood (summerwood) — produced later in the growing season when growth slows due to declining water availability, shorter days, and hormonal shifts. The cambium produces cells with smaller lumens and thicker walls, providing greater mechanical support and resistance to cavitation (air embolism in water columns under tension). Latewood is denser and darker in color than earlywood. (3) Ring boundary — the annual ring boundary is visible because of the abrupt transition from the small, dense latewood cells of the previous year to the large, thin-walled earlywood cells of the new growing season. This contrast creates the visible ring pattern in cross-sections. (4) Dendrochronology — ring width variation correlates with growing season conditions (temperature, precipitation), enabling tree-ring dating and climate reconstruction. Narrow rings indicate stress years (drought, cold); wide rings indicate favorable years. Ring-width chronologies have been constructed spanning thousands of years. (5) Tropical trees — trees growing in non-seasonal tropical climates may lack visible annual rings because cambial activity is relatively uniform year-round. More lignin with fewer cells (A), smaller/thicker cells (B), and no conducting elements (C) describe latewood, not earlywood.

questions.question: A researcher hypothesizes that the root cap senses gravity via sedimentation of starch-filled amyloplasts (statoliths). To test this, the researcher should:
options: Remove all roots and observe shoot growth patterns
Grow plants in zero gravity and record whether amyloplasts still sediment
Measure root length in light vs. dark conditions

Compare gravitropic bending in wild-type roots to starchless mutants (pgm — phosphoglucomutase deficient) — if amyloplast sedimentation is required for gravity sensing, starchless mutants that lack dense starch granules in their columella cells should show reduced or absent gravitropic response; complementation by restoring starch synthesis should rescue the response
questions.explanation: The statolith hypothesis for gravity sensing is one of the most well-studied aspects of plant gravitropism: (1) The hypothesis — specialized cells called statocytes in the root cap columella contain dense, starch-filled amyloplasts (statoliths) that sediment to the bottom of the cell in response to gravity. This sedimentation is detected by the cell and converted into a growth response (gravitropic bending). (2) pgm mutant experiment — Arabidopsis pgm (phosphoglucomutase) mutants cannot synthesize starch, so their plastids lack starch granules and therefore lack the density to sediment. The experimental predictions are: (a) pgm mutants should show reduced gravitropic response (they do — gravitropic bending is present but significantly reduced, suggesting that amyloplasts contribute to but may not be the sole mechanism of gravity sensing). (b) Restoring starch synthesis (genetic complementation or supplying exogenous sugar to promote limited starch accumulation) should rescue gravitropic sensitivity (it does). (3) Columella cells — the gravity-sensing cells are specifically the columella cells of the root cap (not the root meristem or elongation zone). These cells contain 10-20 amyloplasts that sediment within seconds of reorientation. The peripheral cells of the root cap and the lateral root cap cells do not appear to function as primary gravity sensors. (4) Mechanism — amyloplast sedimentation leads to: redistribution of PIN3 and PIN7 auxin efflux carriers in columella cells, leading to lateral redistribution of auxin. On the lower side of a horizontally placed root, increased auxin inhibits cell elongation (auxin at high concentrations inhibits root cell elongation), while the upper side with less auxin elongates faster, causing the root to bend downward. (5) Why other options are wrong — removing roots (A) doesn't test the hypothesis; microgravity (B) tests whether sedimentation occurs in space but doesn't directly test the statolith model with a genetic approach; light vs. dark (C) tests phototropism, not gravitropism.

questions.question: The preprophase band (PPB) is a transient structure of cortical microtubules that forms before mitosis in plant cells. Its primary function is to:
options: Predict the future plane of cell division by marking the cortical site where the cell plate will fuse with the parental cell wall — although the PPB disassembles before metaphase, it leaves a cortical 'memory' involving specific proteins (TAN1, POK1/POK2, RanGAP1) that guide the expanding cell plate to the correct fusion site during cytokinesis
Drive chromosome separation during anaphase
Synthesize cellulose microfibrils for the new cell wall
Transport vesicles from the Golgi to the plasma membrane
questions.explanation: The preprophase band is a uniquely plant-cell structure critical for oriented cell division: (1) Structure — the PPB is a dense band of cortical microtubules that forms a ring at the cell cortex (just beneath the plasma membrane) during late G2/early prophase. It marks the exact position where the cell will divide — the future division plane. (2) Transient nature — the PPB disassembles at the onset of prometaphase (before the mitotic spindle forms), yet the division plane information persists. This means the PPB establishes a cortical 'memory' that guides later events, even though the PPB itself is gone during the actual division. (3) Cortical division site (CDS) — the PPB leaves behind a set of proteins at the cortex that define the cortical division site. Key CDS components include: TAN1 (a basic protein that remains at the CDS after PPB disassembly), POK1/POK2 (PHRAGMOPLAST ORIENTING KINESINS — kinesin motor proteins that help guide the expanding phragmoplast/cell plate to the CDS), RanGAP1 (a regulator of Ran GTPase concentrated at the CDS). (4) Cell plate guidance — during cytokinesis, the phragmoplast (which carries vesicles to build the cell plate) expands centrifugally from the center of the cell toward the cell periphery. As it approaches the parental cell wall, the CDS proteins guide the phragmoplast and cell plate to fuse precisely at the position formerly occupied by the PPB. (5) Significance — the PPB is absent in some cell types that divide symmetrically (e.g., some endosperm cells), and in these cases cell division planes can be irregular. In meristematic cells, the PPB ensures precise division plane orientation, which is critical for organized tissue growth. Chromosome separation (B), cellulose synthesis (C), and vesicle transport (D) are functions of other structures.

questions.question: Mycorrhizal associations significantly enhance plant nutrient acquisition. In arbuscular mycorrhizae (AM), the fungal partner belongs to which phylum, and what specialized structures does it form within root cortical cells?
