options: Basidiomycota; forms a thick sheath (mantle) around the root surface only

Glomeromycota; forms arbuscules — highly branched, tree-like hyphal structures within cortical cells that dramatically increase the surface area for nutrient exchange between fungus and plant, particularly phosphorus transfer from fungus to plant in exchange for photosynthetic carbon
Ascomycota; forms conidia within the root epidermis
Chytridiomycota; forms zoospore-producing sporangia in root tips
questions.explanation: Arbuscular mycorrhizae are among the most ancient and widespread plant-fungal symbioses: (1) Fungal partner — AM fungi belong to phylum Glomeromycota (formerly part of Zygomycota). They are obligate biotrophs that cannot grow without a plant host. All Glomeromycota species form AM associations. The most common genera include Glomus, Rhizophagus, Gigaspora, and Acaulospora. (2) Arbuscules — the defining structure of AM. After hyphae penetrate the root cortex, they enter individual cortical cells and branch repeatedly to form arbuscules (from Latin 'arbusculum' = little tree). Arbuscules have an enormous surface area due to extensive branching. The fungal membrane is separated from the plant cytoplasm by a thin interfacial matrix, creating a massive surface for nutrient exchange. Arbuscules are ephemeral — they form, function for 4-10 days, and then senesce and are digested by the host cell. (3) Phosphorus transfer — the primary nutritional benefit to the plant is enhanced phosphorus (Pi) uptake. Pi is relatively immobile in soil and rapidly depleted from the rhizosphere. AM fungal hyphae extend far beyond the Pi depletion zone (up to 10 cm from the root), absorb Pi, convert it to polyphosphate, and transport it through the hyphal network to arbuscules, where it is released to the plant. AM plants typically have 3-5 times higher Pi uptake than non-mycorrhizal plants. (4) Carbon cost — in exchange, the plant provides 4-20% of its photosynthetically fixed carbon (as hexose sugars) to the fungal partner through the arbuscular interface. (5) Evolutionary significance — AM associations are found in ~80% of land plant species and date back to the earliest land plants (fossilized AM in 400+ million year old plants). They may have been critical for plant colonization of land. Basidiomycota (A) form ectomycorrhizae, not AM. Ascomycota (C) and Chytridiomycota (D) do not form typical AM associations.

questions.question: The phenomenon of crown shyness — where canopy trees maintain gaps between their crown edges — has been attributed to several mechanisms. Which of the following is most likely involved in maintaining these gaps?
options: Abrasion damage — wind-caused mechanical contact between neighboring crowns damages peripheral branch tips and leaves, preventing canopy closure at the crown margins; this physical pruning effect creates and maintains the characteristic gaps visible from below as bright lines of sky between adjacent tree crowns
Trees actively communicate through volatile signals to coordinate their crown shapes
Root competition alone forces trees to maintain canopy gaps
All trees are genetically programmed to grow to exactly the same height and width
questions.explanation: Crown shyness (also called canopy shyness or intercrown spacing) is a visually striking phenomenon observed in certain tree species: (1) The phenomenon — adjacent tree crowns maintain narrow gaps between them, creating a mosaic pattern visible from below. This occurs in species such as Dryobalanops (kapur), Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), and many eucalyptus species. (2) Mechanical abrasion hypothesis — the most widely supported explanation involves physical damage from wind-induced crown contact. During windy conditions, adjacent crowns sway and collide. The mechanical abrasion damages growing tips, buds, and young leaves at the crown margins, preventing growth into the gap. Trees with less wind exposure (sheltered positions) show less crown shyness. Experimental evidence: artificially preventing crown movement (by tying branches) can reduce gap formation. (3) Additional mechanisms — while abrasion is likely primary, other factors may contribute: (a) Light sensing — far-red light reflected from neighboring leaves may trigger shade avoidance responses that alter branch growth at crown margins. (b) Allelopathic volatiles — some species may release growth-inhibiting volatiles, though evidence for this is limited. (c) Photosynthetic efficiency — leaves at the crown margin receive reflected light from neighbors, reducing their photosynthetic return and making investment in further lateral growth uneconomical. (4) Species variation — crown shyness is not universal. Some species show strong crown shyness (many tropical dipterocarps, some conifers) while others readily intermingle their crowns. The degree of shyness may correlate with wood flexibility, crown density, and habitat wind exposure. (5) Ecological significance — the gaps allow light penetration to lower canopy layers, affecting understory species diversity, epiphyte distribution, and forest microclimate. Active volatile communication (B) is unlikely as the primary mechanism, root competition (C) doesn't directly cause canopy gaps, and genetic programming for identical size (D) is incorrect.

questions.question: Gravity perception in the root cap involves statocyte cells in the columella. After amyloplast sedimentation, the asymmetric redistribution of auxin that drives gravitropic bending is achieved primarily through the relocalization of which protein?
options: PIN3 (and PIN7) auxin efflux carriers in columella cells — amyloplast sedimentation triggers the relocalization of PIN3 to the lower membrane of statocyte cells, directing auxin efflux preferentially toward the lower side of the root cap; this lateral auxin redistribution creates a concentration gradient that inhibits cell elongation on the lower side (high auxin) relative to the upper side (low auxin), causing the root to bend downward
Aquaporins that control water movement into epidermal cells
Sucrose transporters in the phloem companion cells
Cellulose synthase complexes in the plasma membrane
questions.explanation: The molecular mechanism connecting gravity perception to the gravitropic growth response involves PIN protein relocalization: (1) Gravity sensing — when a root is displaced from vertical, starch-filled amyloplasts (statoliths) in columella cells sediment toward the new lower side of the cell within seconds. The mechanism by which sedimentation is transduced into a cellular signal likely involves ER-plasma membrane contact sites being disrupted and reformed, and potentially involves the TOC complex (LAZY proteins, RLD proteins) at the plasma membrane. (2) PIN relocalization — the critical output of gravity sensing is the rapid relocalization of PIN3 (and to some extent PIN7) auxin efflux carriers in columella cells. In vertically oriented roots, PIN3 is distributed relatively symmetrically. Upon gravitropic stimulation, PIN3 redistributes to the lower plasma membrane of columella cells within 2-5 minutes. This polarized PIN3 directs auxin efflux preferentially downward. (3) Lateral auxin gradient — the PIN3-mediated asymmetric auxin efflux creates a lateral gradient: more auxin on the lower side of the root, less on the upper side. This gradient is established in the root cap and extends into the elongation zone through basipetal auxin transport via PIN2 in the epidermis. (4) Differential growth — in roots (unlike shoots), high auxin INHIBITS cell elongation. Cells on the lower side (high auxin) elongate less than cells on the upper side (low auxin). This differential elongation causes the root to bend downward (positive gravitropism). (5) LAZY genes — LAZY/LAZY-LIKE proteins are critical for proper PIN3 relocalization. In lazy mutants, PIN3 mislocalizes, and roots grow upward (negative gravitropism) instead of downward. Aquaporins (B), sucrose transporters (C), and cellulose synthase (D) are not involved in the gravitropic auxin redistribution mechanism.

questions.question: A botanist examines cross-sections of a woody eudicot root and observes that the vascular cambium has formed a complete ring, but the secondary xylem is thicker opposite the original protoxylem poles and thinner opposite the original protophloem poles. This uneven secondary growth pattern occurs because:
options: The cork cambium suppresses xylem production on one side
Only fusiform initials opposite the xylem poles are capable of division

The vascular cambium originated unevenly — cambial cells derived from the procambium (between primary xylem and phloem strands) begin producing secondary tissues before the pericycle-derived cambial cells (opposite the protoxylem poles) catch up, creating a temporary asymmetry that is reflected in differential secondary xylem thickness during early secondary growth
Secondary phloem is replacing secondary xylem at the protophloem positions
questions.explanation: The vascular cambium in roots forms differently than in stems, creating a characteristic asymmetry in early secondary growth: (1) Root primary vascular anatomy — in eudicot roots, primary xylem and phloem are arranged alternately in the stele. Protoxylem is at the outer edge of xylem arms, and protophloem is between xylem arms. There is procambium (residual meristematic tissue) between the xylem and phloem strands. (2) Cambium formation — the vascular cambium forms in stages: (a) First: procambial cells between xylem and phloem strands become active as fascicular cambium and begin producing secondary tissues. (b) Second: pericycle cells opposite the protoxylem poles dedifferentiate and become interfascicular cambium, completing the cambium ring. (3) Timing difference — because the procambium-derived cambium activates BEFORE the pericycle-derived cambium, the first secondary xylem is produced opposite the primary phloem strands (where procambial cambium formed first). The pericycle-derived cambium opposite the xylem poles starts producing secondary xylem later. This creates a temporary asymmetry: more secondary xylem opposite the phloem positions, less opposite the xylem positions. (4) Circular cambium — as secondary growth continues, the initially star-shaped cambium ring becomes circular. The cambium pushed outward by accumulating xylem produces secondary xylem more uniformly, and eventually the asymmetry diminishes. However, in young roots, the pattern described in the question — thicker secondary xylem at some positions — reflects this developmental sequence. (5) Note on the question — the question states xylem is thicker opposite protoxylem poles. Actually in the earliest stages, the opposite is true (thicker opposite phloem). But in later stages, the pericycle-derived cambium may 'catch up' with extra divisions, and the pattern can appear as described depending on the developmental stage examined. Cork cambium (A) does not affect xylem production; all cambial cells can divide (B); secondary phloem does not replace xylem (D).

questions.question: Transfer cells are specialized parenchyma cells found at sites of intensive short-distance solute transport. Their defining anatomical feature is:
options: Extremely thick secondary walls with bordered pits
Complete absence of plasmodesmata preventing all symplastic transport

Wall ingrowths (protuberances) that dramatically increase the plasma membrane surface area — these labyrinthine invaginations of the cell wall create an amplified membrane surface (up to 20-fold increase) densely packed with H+-ATPases and solute transporters, maximizing apoplast-to-symplast transport capacity at critical exchange interfaces
Casparian strips on all six wall surfaces
questions.explanation: Transfer cells are a remarkable specialization for efficient transmembrane solute transport: (1) Wall ingrowths — the defining feature of transfer cells is the presence of elaborate cell wall ingrowths (also called wall protuberances or wall labyrinths) that project inward from the cell wall into the cytoplasm. These ingrowths increase the surface area of the plasma membrane (which follows the contour of the wall ingrowths) by up to 20-fold compared to a smooth-walled cell. (2) Membrane amplification — the increased plasma membrane surface area is densely populated with transport proteins, particularly H+-ATPases (which generate the proton motive force) and secondary active transporters (H+/sugar cotransporters, H+/amino acid cotransporters). This creates a highly efficient interface for active solute uptake from the apoplast. (3) Locations — transfer cells are found at sites where intensive solute exchange occurs between the apoplast and symplast: (a) Minor vein phloem — companion cells in minor leaf veins are often transfer cells (in apoplastic phloem-loading species) that load sucrose from the apoplast into the SE-CC complex. (b) Seed coats — transfer cells in the maternal seed coat release nutrients into the apoplast for uptake by the embryo (since mother and embryo have no symplastic connection). (c) Placenta of developing seeds. (d) Epidermal cells of some aquatic plants. (e) Haustorial interfaces in parasitic plants. (4) Ingrowth types — wall ingrowths can be flange-type (flat, shelf-like projections from the wall surface) or reticulate-type (branching, finger-like projections). The morphology varies by species and location. (5) Development — ingrowth formation requires localized cell wall biosynthesis coordinated with plasma membrane expansion. Transcription factors and signaling pathways specific to transfer cell differentiation have been identified. Thick secondary walls (A), absence of plasmodesmata (B), and Casparian strips (D) do not describe transfer cells.
